Konzeption und Implementierung einer automatisierten semantischen Analyse von technischen Regulierungs dokumenten

Emmanuel Dadem
Apr 30 · 6 min read

Emmanuel Dadem in Betreuung von Prof. Dr. Oliver Hofmann

Technische Hochschule Nürnberg — Master Applied Research in Engineering Sciences

Einleitung

Ein Text ist zu verstehen als eine Menge an unstrukturierten Daten, die aus Zeichenketten bestehen und die als Wörter bezeichnet werden [1]. Diese enthalten enorme Menge an Informationen, die vom Menschen natürlich interpretiert werden können. Handelt es sich jedoch um einen Computer, wird dies eher zu einer vergleichsweise komplexen Aufgabe. Zur Lösung solcher Angelegenheit müssen eine Reihe von Techniken aus dem Bereich der künstlichen Intelligenz wie Natural Language Processing (NLP) und Text-Mining eingesetzt werden [2, p. 3].

Problemstellung

Nationale Regulierungsbehörden erlassen weltweit Dokumente um sicherzustellen, dass eine Reihe von Qualitätsvorschriften, z.B. zur Produktion, eingehalten werden, woraufhin die Produkthersteller aufgefordert werden, diese Vorschriften nicht nur bei der Entwicklung neuer Produkte zu berücksichtigen, sondern auch bei jeder Änderung zu beachten.

Die Veranschaulichung und Identifizierung relevanter Dokumente ist mit einem erheblichen personellen Aufwand verbunden. Daher soll die Möglichkeit der maschinellen semantischen Analyse solcher Dokumenten untersucht und die Frage beantwortet werden, ob mit einer solchen maschinellen Vorgehensweise mindestens die Qualität einer manuellen Analyse erreicht werden kann.

Technologie Konzept

Ein wesentlicher Bestandteil der zu entwickelnden Softwarelösung ist die (teil-)automatisierte Erfassung und Auswertung von Regulierungsvorgaben, die in der Regel online verfügbar sind. Folgende Komponenten sind für den Einsatz geplant:

  • zur automatisierten Datenerfassung

Relevante Online-Quellen sollten regelmäßig auf der Suche nach neuen Regulierungsdokumenten (Crawling) konsultiert und diese in vorbereiteter und standardisierter Form in den Textkorpus [3] des Systems aufgenommen werden.

  • zur Analyse des Inhalts des Textes

Die Verwendbarkeit der für die Verarbeitung natürlicher Sprache (NLP) verfügbaren Werkzeuge und Hilfsmittel muss im Hinblick auf die formale Fachsprache von Regulierungsdokumenten bewertet und ein Verfahren entwickelt werden, das eine thematische und inhaltliche Klassifizierung von Dokumenten ermöglicht.

  • zur Bewertung des Korpus von Texten zur Entscheidungsunterstützung

Das System soll Fragestellungen auf Basis der analysierten Regulierungsdokumente bearbeiten, betroffene Dokumente und relevante Textstellen für ein Review durch den Bearbeiter markieren und ggf. eigenständig Antworten generieren.

1) Automatisierte Datenakquisition

Die Regulierungsvorgaben eines Regulierungssystems werden in der Regel im Internet im freien Zugang in der jeweiligen Landessprache veröffentlicht. Basierend auf einer Auswahl von Einführungsreferenzen durchsucht ein Web-Crawler regelmäßig die Websites von Regulierungssystemen und ergänzt oder aktualisiert den Textkorpus mit den gefundenen Dokumenten wie in folgender Abbildung dargestellt. Um die Rückverfolgbarkeit zu gewährleisten, bleiben die alten Versionen dauerhaft sicher.

Zusätzlich zum Originaldokument werden Metadaten (Regulierungssystem, Extraktion Zeitpunkt, Sprache des Originals, etc.) erfasst und gespeichert.

Wenn möglich, sollte auch eine automatische Übersetzung ins Englische von Dokumenten durchgeführt. Diese Daten können bereits ohne eine detaillierte Analyse des Inhalts des Dokuments ermittelt werden. Um die Ausgangssprache und die maschinelle Übersetzung zu bestimmen, ist es notwendig, die auf dem Markt verfügbaren Lösungen zu identifizieren und zu bewerten.

2) Syntaktische Analyse des Textinhalts

Um den resultierenden Textkorpus für automatische Entscheidungen zugänglich zu machen, werden mit Hilfe von Natural Language Processing (NLP) Verfahren über einigen Software-Tools wie Stanford Corenlp [7] konkrete Merkmale aus dem Dokument extrahiert und allgemeinere Texteigenschaften abgeleitet:

  • Tokenization, Lemmatization, Part-Of-Speech: Jedes Satzwort wird dadurch einzeln erfasst und in seine ursprüngliche Form gebracht. Zum Beispiel könnte man zwischen verschiedenen Arten von Substantiven mit Tags wie NN, NNP und NNS unterscheiden, um Singular-, Proper- und Plural-Nomen abzubilden. Verben sind hier beispielsweise durch VB markiert. [4, S.384]
  • Named Entity Recognition: Durch Entitäten wie Personen-, Firmennamen, Zahlen, E-Mails, URL, etc werden im Text automatisch durch dieses Prozess anerkannt wie es unten dargestellt ist. [4, S.381]
  • Open Information Extraction: Es extrahiert die Dreifache-Beziehung, die ein Subjekt, eine Beziehung und das Objekt der Beziehung darstellen wie unten abgebildet. [5, S.160]

3) Entscheidungsunterstützung durch Semantische Textanalyse

Die semantische Analyse liefert Antworten auf die Erwartungen und Fragen des Benutzers in Bezug auf das Dokument, das am Eingang des Prozesses gegeben wurde. Die hier hauptsächlich verwendete NLP-Technik ist die Text-Klassifizierung. Die Textklassifizierung ist eine gesteuerte Machine-Learning-Methode zur Klassifizierung von Sätzen oder Textdokumenten in eine oder mehrere definierte Kategorien oder Labels [2, S.79]. Es handelt sich um eine weit verbreitete Aufgabe der Natural Language Processing, die z.B. bei der Spam-Filterung, der Stimmungsanalyse, der Kategorisierung von Presseartikeln und vielen anderen geschäftsbezogenen Themen eine wichtige Rolle spielt.

Wenn wir zum Beispiel unser Wörterbuch so definieren würden, dass es die folgenden Wörter enthält {The, medical, device, not, should, be, dangerous, bad, labelled}, und wir wollen den Text {Medical device should be labelled} vektorisieren, dann hätten wir die folgende Vektordarstellung dieses Textes: (0, 1, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 1). Dabei stellen die 1 Elemente dar, die bereits in der Vergangenheit beobachtet wurden, und die 0 das Gegenteil.

Anschließend wird der Algorithmus für Machine Learning mit Trainingsdaten angereichert, die aus Paaren von Merkmals Sätzen (Vektoren für jeden Beispieltext) und Tags bestehen, um ein für das Fachgebiet dieses Forschungsprojekts spezifisches Klassifikationsmodell für Dokumente zu erstellen. Die folgende Abbildung zeigt einen Überblick über

diesen Trainings- und Lernprozess von Klassifikationsmodellen [2, S.130].

Mit genügend Beispielen aus dem Training, kann das gebaute Modell nun damit beginnen, Vorhersagen (Predictions) zu machen, indem es neue Texte, die als Eingabe vorgegeben werden, mit den vordefinierten Tags im spezifischen Fachgebiet verknüpft.

4) Systemarchitektur

Die Softwarelösung ist als Webanwendung zu konzipieren, die in der Lage ist, Kundenbedürfnisse mit einer anpassbaren grafischen Benutzeroberfläche und einer maschinen adressierbaren REST-Schnittstelle [6] zu erfüllen, sodass das entwickelte NLP-Werkzeug-Prototyp zur semantischen Textanalyse von Regulierungsdokumenten über konsumierbaren WebService zugregriffen und angesteuert werden könnte. Die Integration in bestehende Benutzeroberfläche sollte so einfach wie möglich sein, basiert auf ihre Effizienz und Effektivität und wird in der Endphase des Projekts ein Gegenstand der Forschung sein.

Zusammenfassung

Die semantische Analyse von Regulierungsdokumenten ist ein innovativer Ansatz, um die zeitaufwändige und arbeitsintensive Prüfung mit automatisierter Hilfe zu vereinfachen. Die besonderen Herausforderungen sind:

  • Die Anwendung von NLP-Tools auf formale Geschäftssprachen
  • Dokumentenklassifizierung und (teil-)automatisierte Antwort Generierung
  • Mandantenfähigkeit bei Verwendung eines gemeinsamen Textkorpus
  • Die intuitive Benutzerfreundlichkeit der Oberfläche für komplexere Fragestellungen mit Bezug auf Effizienz und Effektivität

Literaturverzeichnis

[1] G. Salton, Automatic Text Processing: Transformation, Analysis, and Retrieval of Information by Computer, Addison Wesely, Reading, 1988.

[2] T. J., Text Mining — Concepts, Implementation, and Big Data Challenge. S.3, Springer-Verlag. ISBN 978–3–319–91814–3, 2019.

[3] Wołk, K.; Marasek, K. — Advances in Intelligent Systems and Computing. Springer. 275: 107–114. ISBN 978–3–319–05950–1. ISSN 2194–5357

[4] Charu C. Aggarwal. Machine Learning for Text. Springer-Verlag, 2018. isbn: 978-3–319–73530–6.

[5] M. Banko und O. Etzioni. The tradeoffs between open and traditional relation extraction. ACL Conference, 2008.

[6] Roy Thomas Fielding. Chapter 5: Representational State Transfer (REST). 2000.

[7] Stanford CoreNLP — https://stanfordnlp.github.io/CoreNLP/

]
StoryTitle: Konzeption und Implementierung einer automatisierten semantischen Analyse von technischen Regulierungs dokumenten

Talking about Data Science Topics with Business-Minded Executives

Explanations to effectively communicate technical data science work to a non-technical audience & reduce misunderstanding

Megan Dibble
Follow
Apr 30 · 6 min read

I have heard stories from managers about data scientists who are brilliant in their technical prowess but lack some essential business communication skills. I have also heard data scientists complain about how upper management does not understand the difference between some technical terms and will throw in buzzwords, like “big data”, without understanding their meaning.

The purpose of this article is to help out both sides here! Data scientists, you can read this and get help with explaining jargon in non-technical terms. Business leaders, you can gain some insight into the true meaning of current data buzzwords and perhaps better understand the plight of the data scientist.

Explaining Terms

“Artificial Intelligence! Big Data! Deep Learning! We need to make use of all of these in our organization… ASAP.”

Definition of AI

We can define artificial intelligence as “a program that can sense, reason, act, and adapt.” AI mimics the cognitive functions that humans exhibit, like reasoning and learning.

Definition of Machine Learning

Machine learning is a specific type of AI that uses algorithms to learn patterns in data and output predictions. Machine learning requires relatively large datasets and often data scientists will split the data into a training set (to build the model) and a testing set (to test model performance and generalization).

Definition of Deep Learning

Deep learning is a complex type of neural network (FYI: neural networks are a subset of machine learning). Some people will use the terms neural network and deep learning interchangeably, but really deep learning is when a neural network has at least two hidden layers. If you do not know what hidden layers are, that’s ok, all you need to know is that a deep learning algorithm is more complex (and thus more computationally expensive) than a small neural network.

What Constitutes Big Data?

Big data is a huge buzzword. But what is the difference between having a lot of data and truly having big data at your organization? The graphic above outlines 4 key descriptors that make data considered “big.”

When you are working with big data, the scale is generally measured in terabytes. Big data is data that comes in a variety of formats, like images, text, numbers, and more. And, if your company is also talking about analyzing streaming data (i.e. data that is continuously generated), you are likely dealing with big data.

Eliminating Confusion

“Our company is using cutting edge machine learning technology.”

Machine Learning vs. Data Analysis or Statistics

One big difference between data analysis and machine learning is the questions they seek to answer.

In data analysis, you want to know something like what happened to sales at this point in time in our company? Why might it have happened? In machine learning, you want to know based on what happened in the past, what can we expect will happen to our sales in the future?

The graphic above details some of the business tasks or questions that could be answered with machine learning. For each of these tasks, you are creating a model, training that model with data, and then testing its prediction accuracy (or another metric). Data analysis, on the other hand, is focused on just analyzing trends and then looking for explanations.

Deep Learning vs. Other Machine Learning Algorithms

These graphics highlight the two important distinctions between deep learning and other machine learning techniques (in my mind).

The first graphic explains one of the benefits of deep learning — it completes the process of feature extraction (i.e. creating features from an initial dataset) in addition to performing classification tasks. This means the data scientists can put in raw data into deep learning algorithms, like pixel values in images for example, which they cannot do for other machine learning methods.

The second graphic illustrates how deep learning performs better with large datasets. Depending on the type and amount of data you have, one method will be a better fit for your project than the other. (Computing resources are an important consideration too — training algorithms with lots of data can take lots of time.)

Finally, deep learning methods are most often used in industry with labeled data (i.e. data where the outcome/classification is known). Machine learning methods are often used to model data that is either labeled or unlabeled.

Setting Expectations

“So can you get back to me with a predictive model for that metric* by the end of the week?”

*which is nowhere in our data warehouse

The Workload of Data Cleaning

Forbes published data from a CrowdFlower survey of about 80 data scientists in 2016. The answers to the question “What do you spend the most time doing” are depicted in the pie chart above.

The big takeaway from this survey, which is a statement I have heard many times before, is that data scientists spend up to 80% of their time on data collection and cleaning (in the graph above, collecting data and cleaning/organizing data sums to 79%). I have talked with data scientists who say that executives do not always understand or take into consideration the amount of work that has to go into simply prepping the data for a project.

Accuracy vs. Time Trade-off

This is something that I think about a lot in my personal projects, but it applies to professional ones as well. The first graphic illustrates the general data science process, but often there is iteration after the modeling step before the algorithm is put into production or used for a presentation.

There is an inherent trade-off in this iteration: as you spend more time on a model, its accuracy/performance increases but at a decreasing rate (see: the law of diminishing returns and the part of this graph labeled with a C).

If management asks for a certain accuracy level, e.g. 95%, they must understand that if a data scientist comes back with a model that is 93% accurate, it will take far longer to increase that accuracy by the last 2% than it did to increase accuracy at the beginning of the modeling process.

One Final Thought

I have one last thing to request of the data scientist audience here—be clear and concise on what business question you are going to answer with your model/analysis and how the project will add value to the company. Also, whenever possible, calculate the business impact (ideally in monetary units) of your projects.

I think that if you can obtain technical data science skills, communication skills, and look at projects with a business mindset, you are extremely valuable to any company!

Thank you for reading! Please share this article on LinkedIn or with your team at work if you found it helpful.

If you are looking for more articles with simple explanations of data science topics, check out how I break down the basics of popular machine learning models in my most popular one:

Machine Learning Models Explained to a Five-year-old

Explaining How ML Models Work as Simply as I Can

towardsdatascience.com

]
StoryTitle: Talking about Data Science Topics with Business-Minded Executives

StoryHTML:
[

Learning Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with PyTorch

WeiQin Chuah
Apr 30 · 8 min read

In this tutorial, I will guide you through (1) What is Convolutional Neural Network, (2) How to code in PyTorch (coming soon).

This is the first part of the tutorial where I will explain intuitive idea about CNN and why it is so powerful in computer vision tasks. If you are interested in the hands-on part, please go to the Part 2 (coming soon) of this tutorial where I discuss how to (1) load pre-defined neural network and pretrained weights from PyTorch, (2) build your own neural network and (3) train your own neural network.

No preliminary knowledge is required as I will try to explain everything as layman as possible.

Ready, set, let’s rumble!

So if you are just getting started to learn more about computer vision and deep learning (I am guessing that is the main reason why you are reading this page), you most probably had come across the term Convolutional Neural Network or CNN in short and you probably have some basic idea of how it works as there are many informative tutorials out there regarding this topic. In case you need some good materials to read about CNN: Link1, Link2, Link3.

Provided we have a neural network given to us as shown in Figure 1, we can explain this model by breaking down this model into 4 fundamental pieces: (1) input image, (2) stacked convolutional layers and (3) fully connected layers and (4) output vector.

On the most left hand side is the input image. In this example, we have an image with letter ‘A’ and size of 32x32 (as this is a greyscale image thus only 2 dimension, otherwise it will have a size of 32x32x3 if it is a RGB image).

To the right of the input image, we have multiple layers of stacked CNN with different sizes, show in layered squares. Lets take the C1 feature maps as example here. You may ask how is this C1 feature maps have 3 dimensions and with a smaller size compared to the input image. This is the results of CNN operations. In order to achieve this, we need a CNN layer with the following parameters: input feature size=1, output feature size=6, kernel size(k)=7, stride(s)=1,padding(p)=1. The input and output feature size are the third dimension of the input (in this case the image) and the output (C1 features). The kernel size, striding and padding parameters are the one that is responsible for the change in size (height and weight) of the output.

Definitions:

Padding: Amount of pixels added to the input when it is being processed by the CNN. For more information regarding padding refer to this link.

Stride: Number of steps taken when moving the convolutional kernel/window across the input.

The input image has height and width of 32. By applying the formula provided in Figure 2, the output image will have height and width of (32–7+2(1))/1+1 = 28. As we specified the output to have 6 feature sizes and putting everything together, we ended up with an output of size equal to [28x28x6] which is shown in Figure 1.

Notice in Figure 1, to go from C1 features to S2 features, a method named subsampling is used. The chosen subsampling method in this example is max-pooling (there are also average-pooling which can be used to perform subsampling).

How to choose between max-pooling and average-pooling if you ask, intuitively, you may think of max-pooling is picking the most distinct features extracted from previous CNN operation, meanwhile, average-pooling is smoothing out all features within the convolution window. If you are thinking that picking a distinct feature of an object will give better results for tasks like image classification or object detection then you are correct! However, in most works, researchers will run both experiments to justify this idea.

In our example, the parameters of max-pooling is as follow: k=2, s=2, p=0. Again, using the equation from Figure 2, we can calculate the output size of S1 features: (28–2+2(0)/2)+1=14.

Moving on, to obtain C3 from S2, we have another convolution layer with parameter setting as follow: input size = 6, output size = 16, k=7, s=1, p=1. Then from C3 to S4, max-pooling with parameters k=2, s=2, p=0.

As you may have guessed, the two final layers after S4 are the fully connected layers. An example of fully connected layers is illustrated in Figure 4. Input and output layers are single column multi-row vectors. In our example, the input layer (vector) has a size of [(5x5x16)x1] and output layer of [10x1]. Note that the number (5x5x16) comes from the output size of S4 while the number 10 in output layer is the total number of class we are predicting. It can be any other numbers depending on the task on hand. For example, if you are designing a neural network just to classify apple and orange, then the output layer will have size of [2x1].

The magic happens inside the hidden layers where a process known as backpropagation use the gradient computed from the loss function with respect to the weights (lines connecting the circles are the weights) to update these weights.

Loss function is something like a ruler that measures how well your neural network is performing , provided you know the correct answer to your question. For example, you have an image of a cat and if your neural network classify that image as a cat, then the loss or the result of the loss function will be a low value (close to 0). In contrast, if the neural network classify that image as something else, a dog for instance, the loss will be a large value. This large loss will penalize your neural network by “telling” the neural network “it is doing a bad job”.

Before we can feed the output of layer S4 into the fully connected layers, we need to convert the matrices into a single column vector as it is a mandatory requirement to use a fully connected layer. This process is known as flattening and is illustrated in Figure 5.

Notice in layers F5 and F6, there are two magic numbers: 120 and 84. These are the number of nodes. Referring back to Figure 4, node is represented as a circle in the hidden layer. Thus, now we can say that layer F5 has 120 nodes and F6 has 84 nodes. Furthermore, every node in F5 is connected with every node in F6 and vice versa which creates a dense connection between these two layers. Similarly, every node in F6 is connected to every node in the final output as well as between the input (flattened S4) and F5. By simply stacking the three layers with a finite amount of nodes, we have created a complex model, with 30,120 parameters.

After obtaining an output from our model, how can we go from there to labels? We use the idea of indexing. For example, when I am setting up my neural network, I will also have to design a fixed labels to train my neural network. For example [panda, rabbit, cat, dog, giraffe, elephant] with index “1” = “panda”, “2” = “rabbit” and so on. So if the output of my neural network has the largest value for index 3, for example [0.1, 1.1, 5.3, 2.2, 0.7, 2.3], then we can say it is predicting the label “cat” for the given input image. Note that the position of the labels shall be fixed at all time.

To find the largest value, we can perform the operation known as argmax which simply mean selecting the index of the largest value. However, argmax is not differentiable and in deep learning and neural network, each step is required to be differentiable in order to compute the gradient (as mentioned above, gradient is how a neural network “learns”). So to mitigate this problem, we replace argmax with softmax to convert the output to probability distribution. Note that in Figure 8, the sum of the output vector equals to 1.

Let’s go through this step by step:

Using the same example as before, we are designing a neural network to classify the following 6 animals [panda, rabbit, cat, dog, giraffe, elephant]. We give an image of a cat to our neural network and it returns a single column 6 rows vector. The value of each element in the vector is [0.1, 1.1, 5.3, 2.2, 0.7, 2.3] and is shown in column 2 in Table 1. As mentioned before, we can use argmax to select the largest value and call it a day but when we are designing a neural network, it requires a little bit more effort.

To perform softmax, we first take the exponential of each element in the vector which is shown in column 3 in Table 1. Then we take the sum of all exponential terms which gives us 225.422. By dividing each of the exponential term with the sum, it gives us the output of softmax. Now, to make this idea more concrete to you, the raw output from the neural network can be called scoring function or simple score which simply indicates larger value is favourable. The exponential terms are the unnormalized probabilities while the output of softmax is the normalized probabilities. Again, note the sum of the output is equal to 1. At this point, instead of saying the label cat is selected because it gives the highest score, we can say it is selected because the neural network reported the input image has a probability of 88.9% to be a cat which is the highest among all.

That’s all in this tutorial. In the part 2 of this tutorial, I will cover how to train your own neural network from scratch. That includes discussing about loss function selection and PyTorch library. It will be a more hands-on guide than this one. I will try my best to publish it ASAP.

At the mean time if you are interested in learning more regarding deep neural networks and computer vision, here are some links for you.

Topics :

Gradient Decent & Backpropagation

Computer vision & CNN-1

Computer Vision & CNN-2

Feel free to ask any question in the comment section below.

Enjoy and happy learning!

]
StoryTitle: Learning Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with PyTorch

Developing End-to-End NLP text generator application(part 3) — Using Docker and deploying app locally

Kevin MacIver
Apr 30 · 4 min read

This is the part 3 of a series of stories to show the steps to develop an end-to-end product to help write news articles by suggesting the next words of the text.

On part 1 we focused on generating a Bidirectional LSTM model, check out this link if you haven’t seen it yet:

Developing a End-to-End NLP text generator application(part 1)

In an era of information and technology, written news is a very important mean of communication. With a high volume of…

medium.com

On part 2 we focused on creating a full-stack application with FLASK, check out this link if you haven’t seen it yet:

Developing End-to-End NLP text generator application(part 2) — Full-stack with FLASK, UWSGI and…

This is the part 2 of series of stories to show the steps to develop an end-to-end product to help write news articles…

medium.com

Now that we have structure our full-stack application with frontend, backend and reverse-proxy we can put each part into a separate docker containers.

Which begs the question:

“What is a docker container?”

From the Docker documentation:

“A container is a standard unit of software that packages up code and all its dependencies so the application runs quickly and reliably from one computing environment to another. A Docker container image is a lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, system tools, system libraries and settings.”

So a container has everything you needs to run your application, guaranteeing that the configurations are always the same and your application is portable.

Docker Images

Containers are built based on what are called images. These images are defined by a Dockerfile.

If we remember the tree structures of our project, shown on part 2, we’ll see that each folder has its own Dockerfile.

API

The api Dockerfile is the following:

The FROM command specifies the Parent Image from which you are building. In our case we need a python 3.7 image. Eventually you could choose a ubuntu, windows, or another parent image to build onto.

The WORKDIR sets the working directory for any run, cmd, copy and add instructions that follow it in the Dockerfile.

The ADD instruction copies new files, directories. Therefore in this case we are copying the content of the api folder.

The RUN commands install uwsgi and the libraries set in the api/requirements.txt.

The CMD execute the uwsgi protocol set in the api/app.ini file

CLIENT

The client Dockerfile is the following:

The file follows the same commands as the api/Dockerfile

NGINX

The nginx Dockerfile is the following:

The nginx/Dockerfile starts by loading a nginx image then removing the .conf file from the image and substituting it with our nginx.conf file.

With the three Dockerfiles presented we can build the images to generate each respective container. However, we still need to declare the ports we want to expose for each container in order to allow communication between them.

One approach could be modifying each docker file, build the images and start the containers individually. Another approach is to use docker-compose to tell the docker which image to build and the start order of each container.

Docker-Compose

To enable the use of docker-compose we need to build a docker-compose.yml file as a set of instruction to docker.

The file begins by specifying the api image build and exposing the port 8080 for that container. Then we specify the client image build, exposing the port 6060 and declaring that this container is linked to api so, so api container must be up before client is. Lastly, we specify the nginx container and set the external port to 9080 and route it to port 80 of this container.

This basically states that all traffic through port 9080 is assigned as port 80 of the nginx container.

Deploying Locally

Now that our application, container and docker-compose files are defined we can deploy the app locally by running the docker-compose build and docker-compose up commands.

Conclusion of Part 3

Yeah, we got to deploy our app locally using docker. 🐋

On part 4 we will see how to create pods and deploy our app to the internet using kubernetes in google cloud.

Thanks for reading!

]
StoryTitle: Developing End-to-End NLP text generator application(part 3) — Using Docker and deploying app locally

Linear Regression

WONGVARIT PANCHAROEN
Apr 30 · 3 min read

เป็น Learning Algorithm ที่ใช้ในการหาความสัมพันธ์ของ Dataset กับ Answer ในรูปแบบของ function ที่จะ Predict ให้ค่าออกมาเป็นจำนวนจริงหรือเป็น Real-Value (อย่างตัวอย่างที่ได้แสดงไปในบทที่เเล้ว )

Recap Learning Model

โดยการ Training ของ Linear Regression นั้นในที่นะจะใช้อยู่สองอย่างก็คือ

  1. Gradient Descent
  2. normalEquation

Gradient Descent

จากที่ได้เกริ่นไปในบทที่เเล้ว Gradient Descent มีประโยชน์ในการ หาค่าθ ที่เหมาะสมใน Hypothesis ของเราเพื่อนำไปใช้ในการ Predict โดยใช้ประโยชน์จากการคำนวณ Cost Function โดยการเปลี่ยน θ ไปตาม Cost Function ที่ได้

เราจะใช้ประโยชน์ของ Gradient Descent นี้ในการหาค่า θj ที่เหมาะสมกับโจทย์ของเรากัน

ผมจะใช้โจทย์เดิมที่เคยใช้ในบทที่เเล้ว

ในการ Predict ราคาของแร่ชนิดหนึ่ง เรามีข้อมูลที่ได้มา

(ตัวอย่างข้อมูล จากการ Random โดยสมองน้อยๆ โดยเเถวเเรกคือ น้ำหนักของแร่ เเถวที่สองคือราคา)

เเล้วถ้าน้ำหนัก n จะมีราคาเท่าไหร่ ???

ขั้นตอนการ Applies Linear Regression ลงในโจทย์นี้มีดังนี้

Step 1 : Plot กราฟเพื่อดูเเนวโน้มของข้อมูล

เราจะต้องวิเคราะห์ว่าสมการรูปเเบบไหนที่เหมาะที่จะใช้กับข้อมูลชุดนี้ ที่ดูๆเเล้วเราสามารถใช้สมการเส้นตรงได้ (จริงเเล้วกราฟนี้สามารถใช้ parabora หรือสมการ Degree มากกว่า 2 เพื่อผลลัพท์ที่ดีกว่าได้) เราจะยึดสมการต่อไปนี้เป็นหลัก

y = (θ0) + (θ1)x

Step 2 : เลือก Algorithm

ในที่นี้เราจะใช้ Gradient Descent เนื่องจากเป็นวิธีที่ Classic เเละได้ผลสัพท์ที่ดีเสมอ

Gradient Descent ใช้ประโยชน์จากการคำนวณ Cost Function

(เจาะลึก) Cost Function

Cost Function คือการหาความเเม่นยำ หรือประสิทธิภาพที่เเท้จริง

ความหมายของตัวแปร:

h(x) คือ hypothesis หรือก็คือ function ที่เราคาดเดาว่ามันจะใช้ได้โดยการเเทนค่า θ ที่เราได้มาลงไปในสมการที่เราตั้งในที่นี้คือ y = (θ0) + (θ1)x

xi คือ input จาก example dataset ชุดที่ i

yi คือ exactly answer หรือ ผลลัพท์ที่เเท้จริง ชุดที่ i

เช่น เเร่น้ำหนัก 6 ราคา 305฿ ซึ่ง x = 6 เเละ y = 305

m คือ จำนวนของ Example หรือจำนวนข้อมูลใน Dataset

( h(x)- y )² คือ การคำนวนความเเม่นยำ ยิ่งการเเทนค่า x ลงใน hypothesis เเล้วค่ายิ่งใกล้ y เท่าไหร่ สมการตรงนี้จะยิ่งน้อย

เช่น ในกรณีที่ θ0 = -30 เเละ θ1 = 50 เเทนค่าลงในสมการ y = (θ0) + (θ1)x

h(x) = -30 + 50x เเละ เเทน x=6 ลงไป ผลลัพท์คือ h(6) =-30 + 50(6) = 270

ดังนั้น ( h(6)- y )² ซึ่ง y = 305

ดังนั้น ( h(6)- 305 )² = (270 -305)² =1225

ในกรณีที่ θ0 = -58 เเละ θ1 = 62 ( เป็นค่าที่ใช้ในบทที่เเล้ว )

h(6) =-58 + 62(6) = 314

ดังนั้น ( h(6)- 305 )² = (314 -305)² = 81

จากการเปลี่ยน θ ก็จะเห็นว่า ค่า Cost นั้นลดลงอย่างเห็นได้ชัด เพราะฉะนั้นเมื่อค่า θ เหมาะสมก็จะทำให้ค่า Cost น้อยลด ยิ่งเข้าใกล้ 0 เท่าไหร่ยิ่งดีเท่านั้น

ในส่วนของ 1/(2m) คือการหาค่าเฉลี่ย

กลับมา Gradient Descent

นำ Cost Function ใช้ยังไงล่ะ ?

เราจะนำ Cost Function มาหาอัตราการเปลี่ยนแปลง ( Derivative ) ดังสมการด้านล่าง

เเละเมื่อเขียนสมการใหม่

*** เป็นสมการสำเร็จรูป ไม่จำเป็นที่จะต้องแก้ไขอะไร สามารถนำไปใช้ได้เลย

สมการข้างต้นจะใช้ประโยชน์จากการคำนวนคำนวนค่าเฉลี่ยของการคำนวน Derivative Cost Function ของ Example input เเละ Example Answer ทั้งหมดใน Dataset เเล้วนำไปคูณกับ Learning Rate ( α ) เราจะได้ ทิศทางการเปลี่ยนแปลงของ θ ที่ควรจะเป็น หาก Cost Function มาก θ ก็จะเปลี่ยนไปมาก

Step 3 : Training

เราจะนำสมการที่ได้มาใช้โดยการวนสมการข้างต้นไปเรื่อยๆ ในจำนวน (Iterations) ที่เหมาะสม ไม่เยอะไป ไม่น้อยไป

Step 4 : Check Performance

  • ในการ Train ครั้งเเรกมีโอกาสที่ θ จะได้ค่าที่ไม่เหมาะสมหรือ บางทีก็ได้ค่า NaN (Not a Number ) นั้นเพราะว่า Learning Rate ( α ) ของคุณไม่เหมาะสม คุณต้องลองลดค่า Learning Rate ลง
  • หรือหาก θ ไม่ติด NaN เเต่ไม่ได้ค่าที่เหมาะสม ลง เพิ่ม Iterations หรือเพิ่ม Learning Rate ( α ) ก็เป็น option ที่ไม่แย่

Step 5 : Cheer !!

หากคุณเพียงพอใจกับ θ เเล้วก็สามารถนำไปใช้งานได้เลย หรือหากยังไม่พอใจก็มาต่อกันที่

Next Topic :: Polynomial Linear Regression ⏩ Coming Soon…

]
StoryTitle: Linear Regression

Types of variables in machine learning

Sanjay Nandakumar
Apr 30 · 7 min read

“In God we trust. All others must bring data” - W. Edwards Deming

Introduction

The understanding about types of variables is very important in machine learning process in order to conduct and customize the data processing procedures efficiently. I have often seen some amount of confusion in understanding the grass root meaning of some of these fixed statistical terminologies. In this article, I will explain briefly about the meaning of each type of variables in machine learning with a real life example.

The list of variables covered in this article are-

· Dependent and Independent variables

· Mediating variables

· Moderating variables

· Control variables

· Confounding variables

Dependent and Independent variables

Dependent variables are nothing but the variable which holds the phenomena which we are studying.

Independent variables are the ones which through we are trying to explain the value or effect of output variable (dependent variable) by creating a relationship between independent and dependent variable.

In mathematics, this is generally explained with a formula

y=f(x)

Where,

x= independent variable

y= dependent variable

Which means any changes in x will cause a change in the value of y. The change can be negative or positive.

This is just an association but not the causality.

For example,

We need to predict whether an employee will resign from the job or not. So, we need to analyse the various parameters that influence the mindset of employees. The possible variables or parameters which may influence are-

· Work satisfaction

· Salary

· Distance from home and office

In the above example, we can assume that if the employee is very much satisfied with the job, getting paid with a good salary and the proximity of his/her home from office is very low, then the probability that employee will be resigning from his job is very low. The vice versa output is possible if the independent variables are just as opposite of now. We are very sure that there is a relationship among these variables such that Work satisfaction, Salary and Distance between home and office can have a possible effect and determining power on Resignation. Here, the variables which we use to explain or predict the outcome (Work satisfaction, Salary, Distance between home and office ) are independent variables. The one which is the main phenomena which we are studying about — Resignation is the dependent variable.

Moderating variable

Moderating variable is such a kind of variable which will have a contingent or conditional effect on relationship between an independent and a dependent variable. The strength of relationship between independent and dependent variable may change according to moderating variable.

In the same example as above,If we include an another parameter — “Team coordination and relationship with colleagues”,then the strength of relationship between independent and dependent variable will change.Even though if the independent variables that we considered here has positive effect on outcome,If the employee has poor team coordination and relationship with his/her colleagues,then it may lead to resignation and eventually our prediction will become wrong.The effect of moderating variables might end up in false positive/false negative if not handled properly.

Moderating variables are also sometimes responsible for interaction effect which significantly affect the outcome of many statistical tests like ANOVA and Chi-square.Interaction effects are produced when 2 independent variables have their own influence of outcome on dependent variable but when they are activated together ,they might produce a different outcome.

For example, Let’s say Person X is happy when attending a marriage alone. Person Y is also happy when attending a marriage alone. But when Person X and Person Y together attends a marriage,they might not become happy.This is nothing but an interaction effect because independent variables when interacts together and influences the dependent variable,the possible outcome is changing under same circumstances.

Mediating variables

A mediating or intervening variable is a variable between the independent and dependent variable(in time) and which is supposed to explain the relationship between the independent and dependent variable.

We can assume the following scenario for just an illustrative purpose

John is an employee in XYZ Company

· He is well paid according to industry standards.

· He is satisfied with his job which is software engineering.

· His home is very close to his office

If we look at first 2 points we can suppose that John is highly knowledgeable in his area of expertise and he is working on a project using a technology in which he is very comfortable. Let’s say that his project was based on Java and he is well expertise with Java via his academic and professional history. Due to some circumstances, his company needed to migrate this project from Java to Python.

Now if we analyse the situation,

· John is still very passionate about software engineering.

· John may not feel that much comfort ability in Python as he had in Java.

· He is satisfied with his colleagues and company.

· He is getting paid well.

· His home is near to the office.

In this case, there lies a probability that John might resign and move to another company which is using Java. But still all of the independent variables we measured are indicating positive outcome (John will not resign).Here, the “Knowledge of the employee in the domain” is a carrier through which the independent variables are travelled and transformed into the outcome. Therefore this variable is a mediating or intervening variable.

This is just like a time or carrier variable that takes the independent variable to the dependent variable. Likewise how a postman is responsible for taking the letters from source to destination.

Control variable

A control variable is used in empirical research to reduce the risk of attributing explanatory power of independent variables that in fact are not responsible for the occurrence in variation of dependent variables.

In the same example as above we can consider the following variables also for consideration-

· Revenue and financial stability of the company.

· Economic and political situations of the country.

We have not analysed that the revenue of the company may increase or decrease in each quarter and there by directly influence the salary of its employees proportionally.

Also, the economic and political situation of the country is very important. What if there has been a pandemic, war or a recession?

What if some of the clients backed up from contracts of the company and went to its competitor?

These variables will influence the dependent variable but these are not common occurring scenarios though. If we have taken the measures of our independent variables when these conditions are already present, it may influence the outcome. Even if we are taking the measures amidst of any recession or geopolitical tensions, we must control the effect of these variables such that it will not affect the relationship between the independent variables we chose and the dependent variables.

Confounding variable

A confounding variable is an extra variable that we have not intentionally studied but potentially affect the relationship between an independent and dependent variable. In most of the cases, the effect of confounding variable will result in a biased outcome.

For example, in the same example as above

John is an employee in XYZ Company

· He is well paid according to industry standards.

· He is satisfied with his job which is software engineering.

· His home is very close to his office

We need to analyse that whether John will resign from the job or not. Here, In an overall view, every independent variables look favourable and poised to give an outcome that “John will not resign”. But still there are many confounding variables that will affect the outcome which we have not studied actually.

Likewise,

· Health status of employee

· Family situation of the employee

If the health of John is getting worse, then potentially he will resign from the job even if he is well paid and satisfied with work. Similarly, if his family decided to migrate to a new city, he might resign the job even if all of the independent variables poised to give a positive outcome. These variables which potentially affect the outcome but was not the part of study is called confounding variables.

There are various types of influences that a confounding variable will potentially produce-

· Normative influences

· Non-normative influences

· History graded influences

· Age graded influences

Normative influences

This a type of confounding influence that affects every entity in the dependent variable.

For example, A natural disaster in the country will potentially affect each and every citizen of the country in terms of expenditure and income.

Non-normative influences

This is a type of influence which may not uniformly affect entire data points but may affect some of the sections of the dependants.

For example, a stock market crash will take away the investment of those people who invested in equities but it will not affect those who invested in banks or real estate. These kinds of events which affect only a certain community is called non-normative influences.

History graded influences

This is a type of influence which affects a community at a certain period of time like wars, pandemics, recession etc.

Age graded influences

This is a type of influence which potentially affects the data point at a particular age or fixed time period like marriage, retirement, graduation etc.

Hope you gave got an overall idea.Thanks for reading !!!

]
StoryTitle: Types of variables in machine learning

How To Learn Machine Learning & Deep Learning From Scratch?

Nidhika Sareen
Apr 30 · 2 min read

The key to learning anything is to take baby steps or aim for smaller goals to reach your aim. This strategy will not let you get overwhelmed and also boost your confidence with more minor successes.

Also, there are open resources, free online courses, and other such outlets where you can explore the subject.

For machine learning, you can start with basics to make your fundamentals strong before you move on to more complicated topics for in-depth knowledge.

For basics, you should start learning what exactly is analytics, big data, AI, and data science. You should be able to connect how these domains correlate along with real-world applications.

As you advance, you can start learning about data structures, probability principles, sampling, variables, numerical data, multiple regression, and other related concepts.

Programming language plays a vital role in machine learning. So, try to master python or R or other languages. Again, you need to learn in phases so that you don’t overwhelm yourself.

Similarly, in Deep Learning, you will need to cover topics like Artificial Neural Networks, Natural Language Processing, Convolutional Neural Networks, TensorFlow, and Open CV.

Deep learning applications helped companies like Google & Apple to create Google Assistant & Siri.

You also need to remember to practice your acquired skills to create and execute smaller projects. It will help you master those skills.

Image Source: Unsplash

To Apply Machine Learning Responsibly, We Use It in Moderation

Concerns over implicit bias in machine-learning software raised important questions about how New York Times comment moderators can leverage this powerful tool, while also mitigating the risks.

The NYT Open Team
Follow
Apr 30 · 9 min read

By Matthew J. Salganik and Robin C. Lee

It’s a common refrain on the internet: never read the comments. All too often, the comment section is where trolls and toxic behavior thrive, and where measured debate and cordial conversation ends. The New York Times comment section, however, is different. It is generally civil, thoughtful and even witty. This did not happen by itself; it is the result of careful design and hard work by the Times Community Desk.

For years, people on the Community Desk manually moderated all comments that were submitted to Times articles. The work led to high-quality comments, but it was time consuming and meant that only a small number of stories could be open to comments each day.

In 2017, this changed. To enable comments on many more stories, The Times introduced a new system named Moderator, which was created in partnership with Jigsaw. Moderator is powered by a widely available machine-learning system called Perspective that is designed to help make the comment review process more efficient. After deploying Moderator, The Times dramatically increased the number of stories that are open to comments.

This might sound like another machine learning success story, but it is not that simple.

Since 2017, researchers have discovered that some well-intentioned machine-learning tools can unintentionally and invisibly discriminate or reinforce historical bias at a massive scale. These discoveries raised important questions about how to use machine-learning systems responsibly, and they led us to take a second look at how machine learning was being used in The Times’s comment moderation process.

How a comment makes it onto The Times

When a comment is submitted by a reader, Perspective assigns it a score along a number of dimensions, such as whether the comment is toxic, spam-like or obscene. A comment that includes the line, “free Viagra, free Viagra, free Viagra” might get a high spam score, and a comment that uses a lot of four-letter words might get a high obscenity score. Perspective assigns these scores entirely based on the content of the text; it does not know anything about the identity of the commenter or the article that attracted the comment. In addition to providing scores, Perspective also identifies specific phrases that it thinks might be problematic.

Next, the Community Desk, made up of about 15 trained moderators, reads the highlighted comments for each story and decides whether to approve or deny them for publication based on whether they meet The Times’s standards for civility and taste. This review is enabled by Moderator’s interactive dashboard, which was designed to empower the human moderators, making it easier for them to do their work efficiently and accurately. The dashboard presents the scores and the potentially problematic phrases, as well as other contextual information about the original story.

All of the human moderators have a background in journalism and have been Times employees for many years. In other words, the work of moderation is not outsourced; instead, it is treated as an important responsibility.

Together, this hybrid system combines sophisticated machine learning and skilled human moderators to sift through the thousands of comments submitted each day. It has allowed The Times to foster high-quality conversations around our journalism.

A reason for concern

With the concern about potential bias in machine-learning technology in mind, our colleague Robin Berjon, who is the Vice President of Data Governance at The Times, decided to run an experiment to see if he could trick Perspective, the machine-learning system that powers Moderator. Berjon created duplicate pairs of fake comments with names that are strongly associated with different racial groups to see whether Perspective gave different scores to the comments. It did.

This looked bad for Perspective, but it was actually more complicated. The fake comments that Berjon created didn’t look anything like the real comments that readers submit to The Times — those are typically long and almost never include anyone’s name. And Berjon only attempted to trick Perspective; his fake comments never made it to The Times’s human moderators, who would have detected them.

Despite these limitations, Berjon’s demonstration inspired us to further investigate. We discovered that we were not the first people to be interested in biases in Perspective’s scores.

A team of researchers at the University of Washington assessed Perspective using Tweets and found that the machine-learning software was more likely to rate African-American English as toxic. Researchers at Jigsaw — the very people who created Perspective — published several academic papers attempting to understand, describe and reduce the unintended biases in Perspective. Critically, none of this research was available in 2017 when The Times first started using Perspective as part of the comment moderation process.

Like Berjon’s experiment, this academic research was provocative but incomplete for our purposes. None of it used comments like those submitted to The Times, and none of it accounted for the human moderators who are part of the Times system.

One might suppose that the right response to this research is to build a better machine-learning system without bias. In an ideal world, this response would be correct. However, given the world and the state of current technology, we don’t think that’s possible right now. Roughly speaking, machine-learning systems learn from identifying patterns that exist in data. Because the world contains racism and sexism, the patterns that exist in data will likely contain racial and gender bias.

As an example, a machine-learning system might learn that comments are more likely to be toxic if they include the phrase “Jewish man.” This pattern might exist in the data because the phrase is more frequently used in online comments with the intent to harass. It is not because Jewish men are toxic or because the algorithm is biased against Jewish men.

If the machine-learning system was taught to unlearn this pattern, it could make the system less useful at identifying anti-semitic comments, which might actually make the system less practical for promoting healthy conversation.

Given that a quick technical fix was not possible, we decided to build on prior research and conduct our own investigation to see how these issues might play out in the context of The Times.

Our investigation at The Times

Our investigation of the role of machine learning in Times comment moderation had three parts: digging through the comment moderation database logs; creating comments that tried to trick Perspective; and learning more about the human moderators who ultimately decide whether a comment gets published.

Combing through the database logs of past comments, we wanted to know whether comments scored as more problematic by Perspective were getting rejected by the Times moderators more often. They were. Then, we looked for cases where Perspective and the moderators disagreed. We examined some comments that Perspective scored as risky but were published by The Times’s human moderators, and some comments that were scored as not risky but were rejected. We did not see any systematic patterns related to issues like race or gender bias.

To further test how Perspective works with Times comments, we created a set of 10 identity phrases such as, “Speaking as a Jewish man” and “Speaking as an Asian-American woman,” and we added them to the beginning of one thousand comments that had been published on the Times website. We then had Perspective score all of these modified comments and we compared the results to the scores for the original, unmodified comments.

Similar to what others have found, we saw that these identity phrases led Perspective to score the comments as riskier. But, critically, we saw that these effects were much smaller when the identity phrases were added to real comments, rather than submitted on their own. And we found that the longer the comment, the less impact the identity phrase had on the scores.

The distinctive, and perhaps most important, part of the Times system is the human moderators. We wanted to understand how the moderators used and interpreted the Moderator software to make decisions about what comments to publish on the Times website.

To learn more about the process, we went through comment moderator training and shadowed moderators as they worked. Through observation and discussion, we learned that the moderators felt free to overrule the scores generated by Perspective (and from the log data we could see that this did indeed happen).

The human moderators were keenly aware of Perspective’s limitations, yet they found Moderator’s user interface to be helpful, especially the way it highlights phrases in comments that might be problematic. They told us that having comments ordered by estimated risk makes it easier to make consistent decisions about what to publish.

To be clear, Perspective is not perfect and neither are the human moderators. However, creating a system that maximizes the number of Times stories that allow comments, while also fostering a healthy and safe forum for discussion, requires trade-offs. An all-human model would limit the number of stories that are open for comment, and an all-machine-learning model would not be able to moderate according to The Times’s standards.

Just as Perspective and the moderators are imperfect, so is our investigation. We ruled out large patterns of racial and gender bias, but we might have missed small biases along these dimensions or biases along other dimensions. Also, our investigation happened during a specific point in time, but both Perspective itself and the comments submitted to The Times are always changing.

Overall, our three-pronged investigation of the role of machine learning in comment moderation at The Times led us to conclude that the system — one that combines machine learning and skilled people — strikes a good balance.

General recommendations

Our investigation focused on the role of one specific machine-learning system in comment moderation at The Times. However, the concerns that sparked our investigation apply to all machine-learning systems. Therefore, based on our investigation, we offer three general recommendations:

Don’t blindly trust machine-learning systems
Just because someone tells you that a tool was built with machine learning does not mean that it will automatically work well. Instead, examine how it was built and test how it works in your setting. Don’t assume that machine-learning systems are neutral, objective and accurate.

Focus on the people using the machine-learning systems
An imperfect machine learning tool can still be useful if it is surrounded by dedicated, experienced and knowledgeable people. For example, it did not matter if Perspective occasionally produced inaccurate scores as long as the human moderators ultimately made the correct decisions. Sometimes the best way to improve a socio-technical system is to empower the people using the machine-learning system; this can be done by providing training on how the system works and by giving them the authority to push back against it whenever necessary.

Socio-technical systems need continual oversight.
The initial deployment of a machine-learning system can require difficult technical and organizational changes, but the work does not end there. Just as organizations routinely audit their operation and accounting, they should regularly assess the use of machine-learning systems.

The New York Times has created a thriving comments section through years of effort and innovation. We hope this investigation contributes to that long-term project and also serves as a blueprint for examining the responsible use of machine learning in other areas.

Matthew J. Salganik was a Professor in Residence at the New York Times, and he is a Professor of Sociology at Princeton University, where he serves as the Interim Director of the Center for Information Technology Policy. He is the author of “Bit by Bit: Social Research in the Digital Age”. Follow him on Twitter.

Robin Lee is a PhD student in Sociology at Princeton University. He was a Data Analyst for the Data & Insights team at The New York Times. Outside of work, he’s a data meetup organizer. Follow him on Twitter.

]
StoryTitle: To Apply Machine Learning Responsibly, We Use It in Moderation

A First Look at the Recommendation System with Matrix Factorization and Neural Nets

Lz
Apr 30 · 6 min read

Today, we are going to look at the idea of collaborative filtering for recommendations with the matrix factorization method and neural network embeddings. The data we are going to use today is the classic MovieLens 100k dataset. It has 100,000 ratings applied to 9,000 plus movies by 600 plus users.

Imagine a situation when you want to recommend movies to a user but do not have information about the user other than some past movie ratings. You also do not have other information about a movie other than its ratings by different users. What should you do? Collaborative filtering method comes in handy. The basic idea is the following: let’s find out people who have watched and rated similar movies like you and find out what they have liked and assume that you will also like it.

Matrix factorization and neural nets are two common approaches. Let’s look at the two approaches with the working example of predicting ratings in MovieLens 100K.

Matrix Factorization

The idea of matrix factorization is to find two latent spaces. One is user latent space denoted by U and another is movie latent space denoted by M. Suppose the movie rating data is of dimension 600 * 9000. Then the dimension of U will be 600 * num_latent_vectors. The dimension of M will be num_latent_vectors * 9000. The number of dimensions for user latent space and movie latent space is an empirical question.

An illustrative image will help. We can see from the above image that the first guy likes Harry Potter, Shrek, and The Dark Knight Rises reflected as positive values around 1 in the first row of the matrix. In the image above, the two columns on the left are the embeddings (preferences) of the users. It may reflect styles of a movie. For example, let’s say the first column captures a user’s preference for sci-fi movies and the second column captures a user’s preference for romance movies. Specifically, 1 and 0.1 in the first row indicates the first guy’s preferences for sci-fi style movies and romance movies. The top rows are the embeddings for movies. It can encode information about the styles of a movie. For example, the first row of the first column in the movie embedding may reveal the degree of sci-fi of Harry Porter and the second row of the second column may reveal the degree of romance of Harry Porter. By taking the dot product of users’ preferences U and movies’ attributes M, we can get an approximate for the ratings. Using this method, we can predict the many unobserved ratings in the data and suggest to user movies that they will like.

The objective function will then be to minimize the squared distances between the observed ratings and predicted ratings.

Singular value decomposition is popular approach. Specifically, it is of the following form:

SVD can be achieved simply in python:

from surprise import SVD
from surprise import Dataset
from surprise.model_selection import cross_validatedata = Dataset.load_builtin('ml-100k')
algo = SVD()
# Run 5-fold cross-validation and print results.
cross_validate(algo, data, measures=['RMSE', 'MAE'], cv=5, verbose=True)

We can see the result is relatively good. The mean RMSE across 5 folds cross validation is 0.93 close to benchmark results for this data (here).

Neural Nets Embedding

Another common approach is to use embeddings in a neural networks.

Similar to the idea of matrix factorization, we can also use Keras to create embeddings for the users and movies.

We are going to go through several different models. The first one is very similar to matrix factorization. For the embeddings for both users and movies, we start out with random numbers and then fit a model to learn the embeddings (we compute the dot product of the two embeddings to get the predicted ratings):

# indentations are mysteriously off in mediumdef create_embed(n_latent_factors, n_movies, n_users):
    user_input=Input(shape=(1,),name='user_input',dtype='int64')
        user_embedding=Embedding(n_users,n_latent_factors,name='user_embedding')(user_input)
    
    user_vec=Flatten(name='FlattenUsers')(user_embedding)
    user_vec=Dropout(0.40)(user_vec)
    
    movie_input=Input(shape=(1,),name='movie_input',dtype='int64')
     movie_embedding=Embedding(n_movies,n_latent_factors,name='movie_embedding')(movie_input)
   
    movie_vec=Flatten(name='FlattenMovies')(movie_embedding)
    movie_vec=Dropout(0.40)(movie_vec)
    
    sim=dot([user_vec,movie_vec],name='Simalarity-Dot- Product',axes=1)
    
    return user_vec, movie_vec, user_input, movie_input, sim

We can then begin to train a model based on dot product of embeddings. I chose 20 epochs, batch size to be 128 for illustrative purposes and this is already enough for getting good results.

user_vec, movie_vec, user_input, movie_input, sim = create_embed(50, n_movies, n_users)
model_v0 = Model(inputs=[user_input, movie_input], outputs= sim)
opt = Adam(lr=0.001)
model_v0.compile(loss= root_mean_squared_error, optimizer=opt)history_v0 = model_v0.fit([train.userId,train.movieId],train.rating, batch_size= batch_size, epochs =epochs, validation_data = ([valid.userId,valid.movieId],valid.rating),
                              verbose = 1)

With this model, we can achieve a validation loss of about 0.8, which is an improvement from matrix factorization method. Let’s see if we can improve more.

Let’s see if we can improve the results by using the dot product of the embeddings as input a very small neural net.

def model_v1(user_input, movie_input, sim): # dot product as input
    
    nn_inp=Dense(96,activation='relu')(sim)
    nn_inp=Dropout(0.4)(nn_inp)
    nn_inp=Dense(1,activation='relu')(nn_inp)
    nn_model =keras.models.Model([user_input, movie_input],nn_inp)
    nn_model.summary()
    
    return nn_modeluser_vec, movie_vec, user_input, movie_input, sim = create_embed(50, n_movies, n_users)
model_v1 = model_v1(user_input, movie_input, sim)
model_v1.compile(optimizer=Adam(lr=1e-3),loss= root_mean_squared_error)history_v1 = model_v1.fit([train.userId,train.movieId],train.rating, batch_size= batch_size, epochs =epochs, validation_data = ([valid.userId,valid.movieId],valid.rating),
                              verbose = 1)

We can see that there is indeed an improvement. The validation loss is about 0.68 now.

I am also curious to see if what will happen if I concatenate the user embedding and movie embedding as inputs for a small neural net.

def model_v2(user_input, movie_input, user_vec, movie_vec): 
    
    nn_inp = Concatenate()([user_vec, movie_vec])
    nn_inp=Dense(96,activation='relu')(sim)
    nn_inp=Dropout(0.4)(nn_inp)
    nn_inp=Dense(1,activation='relu')(nn_inp)
    nn_model =keras.models.Model([user_input, movie_input],nn_inp)
    nn_model.summary()
    
    return nn_modelmodel_v2 = model_v2(user_input, movie_input, user_vec, movie_vec)
model_v2.compile(optimizer=Adam(lr=1e-3),loss= root_mean_squared_error)history_v2 = model_v2.fit([train.userId,train.movieId],train.rating, batch_size= batch_size, epochs =epochs, validation_data = ([valid.userId,valid.movieId],valid.rating),
                              verbose = 1)

We see the final validation loss is about the same as the previous model of about 0.68 (slightly higher to 0.688). We can see that the results from using neural nets are all in general better than matrix factorization.

There are other ways that may improve the model such as incorporating movie features, and user features if available. There are also probabilistic models that claim to do well (e.g. hierarchical Poisson factorization).

Hope you enjoyed reading this article! :)

References:

CF Based RecSys by Low Rank Matrix Factorization

Deep Learning With Keras: Recommender Systems

In this post we'll continue the series on deep learning by using the popular Keras framework to build a recommender…

www.johnwittenauer.net

Das Ende der Dokumente?

turicode AG
Apr 30 · 3 min read

Die digitale Transformation steht bei vielen Unternehmen ganz oben auf der Agenda und mit der momentanen Situation, ausgelöst durch Covid-19, hat der Umschwung nur noch mehr an Geschwindigkeit zugelegt. Ein Teil dieser Entwicklung besteht in der Digitalisierung von Dokumenten, was bereits einige Unternehmen und öffentliche Institutionen in Angriff genommen haben und so täglich immense Mengen an Daten sammeln.

Diese Entwicklung kann einem zu der Frage bringen: Werden wir einen Zeitpunkt erreichen, wo wir nicht mehr mit Dokumenten arbeiten werden?

Dokumente verstehen: Unterschied zwischen Mensch und Maschine

Um diese Frage beantworten zu können, muss man zuerst hervorheben, wie unterschiedlich Menschen und Maschine Dokumente verstehen.

Maschinen können nur strukturierte Daten verarbeiten. Darunter versteht man eine einfache Anordnung von Zahlen und Buchstaben. Die Informationen können so direkt aus diesen Reihen herausgelesen und verwendet werden. Dokumente hingegen haben einen komplexeren Aufbau. Jedenfalls die klassischen Formate, welchen wir im alltäglichen Sinne begegnen, wie PDFs, Scans oder E-Mails. Die unterschiedlichen Versionen von Layouts, inhärente Logik und Kontexte erschweren die automatisierte Verarbeitung mit Hilfe von Programmen.

Dafür braucht es den Menschen. Durch wiederholtes Lesen und Verarbeiten von Texten über die Jahre hinweg, sind wir darauf trainiert Dokumente schnell und effizient zu analysieren und können die wichtigsten Punkte oder Kernaussagen praktisch beim Überfliegen verstehen. Der Mensch ist somit Spitzenreiter, wenn es um die Verarbeitung von unstrukturierten Daten geht.

Doch mittlerweile wird Maschinelles Lernen immer besser und leistet einen grossen Beitrag bei der Umwandlung von unstrukturierten in strukturierte Daten.

Der Mensch als unerschöpfliche Quelle für Dokumente

Kommt es also zum Ende der Dokumente?

Es gibt einen Faktor, welcher dieses Szenario eher unwahrscheinlich, wenn nicht sogar unmöglich erscheinen lässt: Die Kreativität des Menschen. Solange Menschen neue Ideen haben und diese in schriftlicher Form untereinander austauschen, werden wir wahrscheinlich auf Dokumente als Kommunikationsmittel zurückgreifen. Der Prozess der Kreativität und Interpretation kann nicht auf einen Code heruntergebrochen werden.

Wenn wir ein Problem entdecken, verwenden wir unsere bisherigen Erfahrungen, zusammen mit äusseren Einflüssen, um eine Lösung zu finden. Die äusseren Einflüsse bestehen zu einem Teil aus der Auswertung und Erkenntnisgewinnung von strukturierten Daten, wie auch aus Rückmeldungen von unseren Mitmenschen.

Dies ist nur ein Beispiel dafür, wie wir Dinge analysieren und erschaffen. Ein Prozess, welcher zu komplex und individuell ist, um ihn in einer standardisierten Reihe von Zahlen und Buchstaben zusammenzufassen.

Berge von Festplatten anstatt Berge von Akten

Es ist davon auszugehen, dass Dokumente so schnell nicht von der Bildfläche verschwinden werden. Es ist aber von einer Abnahme ihrer physischen Form auszugehen, auch weil immer mehr Firmen und Institutionen zur Digitalisierung beitragen und diese vorantreiben.
Die Zahl der digitalen Dokumente hingegen, ist in den letzten Jahren rasant angestiegen und man geht davon aus, dass die Menge an unstrukturierten Daten in den nächsten Jahren exponentiell steigen wird.

Die Zahlen zeigen: rund 2,5 Billionen PDF-Dokumente werden jedes Jahr erstellt und im Jahre 2019 wurden jeden Tag um die 293 Milliarden E-Mails verschickt. Die IDC (International Data Corporation) schätzt, dass im Jahre 2025 unsere weltweite Datenproduktion 175 Zettabytes erreichen wird. Dabei handelt es sich um das zehnfache der Datenproduktion von 2017 und beim grössten Teil wird es sich dabei um unstrukturierte Daten handeln.

Wie bereitet man sich auf eine solche Datenmenge vor? Der erste Schritt wurde bereits von vielen eingeleitet: die Digitalisierung ihrer Dokumente. Der nächste Schritt ist ein System, welches es ermöglicht, die steigende Anzahl von Dokumenten zu organisieren und welches sie von unstrukturierten, in strukturierte Daten umwandelt.

Auch wenn Maschinen zwar den Prozess des Dokumente Lesens und Verstehens nicht für uns übernehmen können, so sind sie dennoch eine grosse Hilfe bei ihrer Organisation und Auswertung.

Um mehr über turicode zu erfahren, besuchen Sie www.turicode.com oder schreiben Sie uns eine E-Mail an info@turicode.com

]
StoryTitle: Das Ende der Dokumente?

Unleash ‘The Power of Data’

Samisha Ladkar
Apr 30 · 6 min read

Struggling with data?? Don’t know where to start from??

Being a beginner I started reading various articles, blogs, posts to start studying data science. While dealing with datasets I understood its really important to first know the data.

Whatever format the data is in, it usually takes some time and effort to read the data, clean and transform it, and check that everything made it through the translation process intact.

So, from where should we start??

  1. I usually start by examining one variable at a time, finding out what the variables mean, looking at distributions of the values, and choosing appropriate summary statistics.
  2. Try to identify possible relationships between variables, I look at tables and scatter plots, and compute correlations and fits.
  3. If there are apparent relationships between variables, I try to investigate more complex relationships.
  4. When reporting statistical results,it is important to answer three questions: How big is the effect? How much variability should we expect if we run the same measurement again? Is it possible that the apparent effect is due to chance?
  5. Then I try to visualize data, try to find what story the data tells. Then, you can deep dive to gain insights from your data.

To get started all you need is the curiosity to ask right questions and a software package like R or Python. After some point of time, you’ll realize that when you are struggling at improving model’s accuracy or are stuck somewhere. In such situation, data exploration techniques will come to your rescue.

Let’s get started…

We will try to implement the above mentioned steps to analyze the website medium.com.

Medium is one of the most famous tools for spreading knowledge about almost any field. It is widely used to published articles on ML, AI, and data science.The dataset contains articles, their title, number of claps it has received, their links and their reading time.

Ask ‘RIGHT’ Questions

What exactly do you want to find out? Where will your data come from?

For our analysis we want the answers to the following questions

How to write a good article? How to inform the reader in an interesting way? What sort of title attracts more crowd? How long an article should be?

How does the data ‘LOOK’ ?

We will use pandas dataframe object to view data.

df = pd.read_csv('medium.csv')
df.head()

A variable is any characteristics, number, or quantity that can be measured or counted. Here, we can see that the variables consists of:

  • Tag : Tagged under AI/ML or DL
  • Name: Name of the author
  • Title: Title of the article
  • Body: Body of the article (Subject)
  • Upvotes: number of upvotes received
  • Date: Date it was published
  • Comments: Number of comments
  • Link: Link to the article

Explore ‘One By One’

Start exploring variables one by one.We need to understand how the data is distributed.

  1. Tag variable

Here, we can see that the tags are categorized under Artificial Intelligence,Deep Learning and Machine Learning.Maximum articles are tagged under Machine Learning followed by Deep Learning followed by Artificial Intelligence.

2. Name

len(data['2.Name'].unique())

Using the above function we find that there are 96 unique authors writing in the field of AI, ML and DL.

3. For sometime we will keep the variables title and body aside as they are in text format.

4. Upvotes

As we know upvotes determine approval for a particular article that means it is a numerical value.But, when we examine data we find they are in the form of string.

‘12.9k’ is NOT EQUAL to 12900!! What do we do now??

We need to preprocess the text to get numerical values.

for i in range(0,len(data)):
    if 'K' in data["5.Upvotes"][i]:
        data["5.Upvotes"][i]= int(float(data["5.Upvotes"][i].replace("K",""))*1000)
    else:
        data["5.Upvotes"][i] = int(data["5.Upvotes"][i])

After processing the data will look like:

Now we are ‘READY’ to explore variable Upvotes

data['5.Upvotes'].mean()

We find that articles tagged under AI/DL/ML gets about 4000 upvotes.

Bored of knowing one variable…

Let’s start to find relations between different variables.We will try to find out 1. Authors who got maximum upvotes.

Adam Geitgey has the most number of upvotes.

2.Find the number of articles written by authors

Adam Geitgey and James Lee have published the most of number of articles

From the above exploration we found that Adam Geitgey has the most number of upvotes even though James Lee and Adam Geitgey wrote same number of articles.

Vishal Maini has more number of upvotes with comparatively less number of posts, shows us that he is a quality author.

Let’s ‘DIVE DEEPER’ and find ‘THE RESULTS’

What was the time when most of the articles were written?

Maximum articles were written in the month of June and May.

Maximum upvotes were observed in the months of May and August.

‘LONG ARTICLES’ ==’MORE UPVOTES’ ???

Relationship between text length and upvotes show that readers also care about length of text along with its quality.

What words in TITLE ATTRACT the most?

Words like machine,data,neural,learning,python,machine,AI,artificial occur maximum times in titles.

It clearly shows that as occurrence of top ten words increases, the upvotes received also increases.

Well, Title writing is an art and with enough data one can comprehend it.

From the above analysis we found out-

Most of the articles were written in the months of May and June whereas most of the articles were read in the months of May and August.Readers tend to loose interest with an increase in the length of an article.Most of the articles are tagged under AI/DL/ML.Authors should focus on the quality of article rather than writing multiple articles as we observed that authors with same number of posts have different number of upvotes .Including top 10 words in title can attract readers.

‘NEXT QUESTIONS’ FOR FURTHER EXPLORATION

Why do authors write more in the months of May and June?

  • Is it because of summer vacations? If we assume its because of summer vacation that means most of the authors may be university students.But we need to investigate ahead and collect right data.

Why the number of upvotes higher in the months of May and August?

  • As assumed earlier about summer vacations in May and June we can say that readers start reading more than their daily reading time in vacations as they try to learn new things.But whats with August??-needs investigation ahead

Can we find out the reading trends?

  • ML/DL/AI are the most comman reading categories among readers.This might be due to changing technologies and the demand in such skills people want to learn them.

Hope you all have got some basic idea on how to begin and how to explore data further to answer questions and find new questions from the insights obtained.

For more information and python code check the below mentioned git repository.

samisha98/MediumSite-Analysis

Contribute to samisha98/MediumSite-Analysis development by creating an account on GitHub.

github.com

]
StoryTitle: Unleash ‘The Power of Data’
