Protecting Core ML Models

Exploring various methods to protect your valuable on-device IP

Georguy
Follow
Apr 30 · 5 min read

The problem

If your in-house mobile machine learning model gives you an advantage over your competitors, you’ll probably want to keep it private. Unfortunately, at the moment, Apple doesn’t offer any approaches to keep Core ML models private.

Anyone can get your .mlmodel file (or the compiled version mlmodelc) and reuse it in third party applications. In this article, you’ll learn a few strategies for protecting your Core ML models.

How other developers can access your models

As we know, an IPA file that we get when we archive a project is just a ZIP. And there are numerous ways to get access to your app folder (e.g. using Apple Configurator 2, iTunes < 12.7, Jailbreak).

Yes, an app bundle doesn’t store a familiar .mlmodel file. Instead, it stores a compiled version of it named mlmodelc, which is just a folder that also contains all your model’s info.

And after a small investigation of your mlmodelc, other developers could integrate this model in their own app using the MLModel API.

ML models, and data underlying them, are valuable IP. It’s essential to consider how to protect them when building mobile ML experiences. Our free ebook explores this challenge and many others in the project lifecycle.

How can we protect models

I see a few options:

Rename mlmodelc

If your model is not proprietary, but you want to support a minimum level of security, you can rename mlmodelc to e.g. .storyboardc, add it to your project, and at runtime change the name back and use it with the MLModel API.

Write custom layers

Another technique is to write custom layers on-device. Leave your model unfinished and require additional layers. The model will be useless without its full implementation.

Download models on demand

You can always download models from a backend on demand in runtime and save them in the app documents folder. Only a jailbreak will allow access to documents. Also, you can remove the downloaded model from docs before closing the application in order to minimize the time it’s kept on-device.

Encrypt/Decrypt model

Last but not least, you can encrypt your model before adding it to a project, and decrypt it at runtime on demand.

All of these above options can be suitable for different conditions and, respectively, require different levels of development complexity. For example, if you just need to support a minimum level of security, as I wrote above, you can just rename a model’s folder — a small kind of obfuscation.

Alternatively, you might opt to not finish your model and write some network’s layers manually — other developers still can investigate your model’s architecture, but not gain full access to it.

Another choice would be to store your models on a backend (or any cloud service, e.g. AWS) and download them every time a user starts your application. But if your models are large and you think that your users won’t like downloading it every time (e.g. if they use cellular network), I recommend using the last option — encrypting/decrypting your models. We’ll explore this technique below.

Securing your IP when working with ML on mobile is crucial. Fritz AI has the tools and expertise to help you do just that.

Model encryption/decryption

This option consists of two phases. First, we encrypt our .mlmodel file on a laptop and add an encrypted version as a resource to our project. And second, at runtime we decrypt this file and build our model using the MLModel API.

All we need to do to encrypt our .mlmodel is write a command line tool named mlmodelencoder, which will take two arguments:

  • path to your .mlmodel;
  • secret key — your passphrase, used for decryption.

If you aren’t familiar with creating a CLT based on Swift, please read this article by John Sundell.

Our MLEncoderTool class looks like this:

The logic is pretty straightforward. The whole encryption process takes place in MLCryptor.

This is an enum that encapsulates two implementations. If your app supports devices with iOS >=13, you can use Apple’s CryptoKit. In other cases, we’ll use RNCryptor (under the hood, it uses Apple’s CommonCrypto).

Note: out of the box, you cannot create a SymmetricKey just by passing a string as argument. So here is a small extension that allows you to do it:

After building your tool, you can call it from the terminal.

MBP-Georgij:~ georguy$ mlmodelencoder your.mlmodel your_secret_key The file was encrypted successfully.

If the file is encrypted successfully, in your current folder (where you called mlmodelencoder) you’ll find a new encrypted version of your model — your.mlmodel.enc.

Great. We’re halfway there. All we have to do is decrypt the file at runtime on iOS. The function for this also looks pretty simple:

Where cryptor is also the MLCryptor’s instance (you should reuse it on both platforms). Then you can save the decrypted data and use the MLModel API to work with it.

In the end

As I wrote above, all described approaches are suitable for different conditions. Choose one that best suits your goals. Or you can combine them if you’d like, for extra layers of obfuscation.

If you know of other methods, please contact me here @eigeorguy. And I hope in the near future, Apple provides us a native way to keep our models private.

Editor’s Note: Heartbeat is a contributor-driven online publication and community dedicated to exploring the emerging intersection of mobile app development and machine learning. We’re committed to supporting and inspiring developers and engineers from all walks of life.

Editorially independent, Heartbeat is sponsored and published by Fritz AI, the machine learning platform that helps developers teach devices to see, hear, sense, and think. We pay our contributors, and we don’t sell ads.

If you’d like to contribute, head on over to our call for contributors. You can also sign up to receive our weekly newsletters (Deep Learning Weekly and the Fritz AI Newsletter), join us on Slack, and follow Fritz AI on Twitter for all the latest in mobile machine learning.

]
StoryTitle: Protecting Core ML Models

StoryHTML:
[

Machine Learning: Predicting the Path of Storms

Christopher Hines
Apr 30 · 10 min read

Can characteristics of the moon be used to predict the path of hurricanes?

Introduction

Our previous blog post focused on a data analytics exercise to examine the unlikely relationship between characteristics of storms and properties of the moon. Unsurprisingly the long established belief that no such meaningful relationship exists held true. Some correlations surfaced but they were mild. However, an interesting side effect from that study was that a merged dataset was generated. Specifically, data related to storms and the position and illumination of the moon were collapsed into a single object. We can now see dates on which storms occurred and what properties of the moon were prevalent on the same dates. We have the data so why not perform some machine learning. Before we do, let’s set a few concepts. More importantly, let’s also frame questions so we know what we are trying to accomplish.

Machine Learning

Machine learning is a discipline of artificial intelligence that focuses on computers inferring new knowledge, and possibly new behaviors based on that knowledge, from historical data. Historical data is sometimes referred to as experience. There are two (2) major subgroups of machine learning — supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

Supervised Learning

Supervised learning is the example we’ll be doing today where data is introduced to some algorithm (a process known as “ training “) to produce a model. A model is a construct used to perform some operation on new (but structurally similar) data that was not a part of training. Let’s consider a very simplified example, say your business wants to predict the growth of sales in a particular region. You have historical sales data by week going back ten (10) years. There is also matching dollar amount spends on marketing by channel going back a similar ten (10) years. Its possible to combine these two (2) sources to form a training dataset (the computer’s “experience”), then feed it into a machine learning algorithm. This would create a model that establishes the relationship between your marketing spends and your resulting sales.

However, that’s not where your business realizes value from machine learning.

Now you need to use the trained model to predict the result you need. You need the model to answer the question concerning growth in sales. This is done by feeding the trained model planned marketing spends for it to predict future sales. That’s the value proposition of supervised learning.

Unsupervised Learning

Unsupervised learning is where an algorithm tries to detect groups in a dataset. There is no training phase. This is commonly accomplished by finding centroids, or hubs, in the data. The algorithm will then find records in the data that are reasonably similar to each hub and group them. It does this by using some approach to estimate the distance of each record from each hub.

For example, let’s say we have a dataset of cars that has each vehicle’s horsepower, engine displacement, mpg, and range. Our goal would be to estimate which record is a sports car, luxury car, or economy car. We will notice that we have three (3) buckets for each type of car. This implicitly provides us with the number of centroids we need to create our model. It’s actually the “k” in probably the model popular algorithm for unsupervised learning, k-means clustering. The algorithm would create our three (3) centroids then try to group each record in the dataset into one of the three (3) matching groups by measuring their commonalities using the available columns. That is, it would try to associate each record with a group based on similarities in horsepower, displacement, mpg, and range.

Now that we understand what machine learning is and what it can do, let’s frame questions we want to answer in this article, and then get into the details of the example.

Developing the Question

We previously mentioned having a merged dataset of storm and moon data by date. A possible interesting direction to take this exercise would be to try to predict the position of hurricanes in the dataset through latitude and longitude coordinates. It would also be interesting to extend that exercise to find the best performing machine learning algorithm for our hurricane prediction model. That is, among the dozens of algorithms available to perform machine learning, which works best for this particular example. Therefore, our two questions could be:

  • Is it possible to accurately predict the position of a hurricane using the data we have?
  • Which machine learning algorithm(s) is best suited for predicting the position of a hurricane using the data we have?

Let’s get started.

Preparing the Data

Fortunately the data is ready-made from our previous post on data analytics and there is not much more work needed to prepare it. The most interesting step here would be to split the data into two parts — one part for training the algorithm into a model, and another for testing the model. The approach we’ll be taking is as follows:

  1. Split the merged data into two datasets, one for training and another for testing. The latest record in the data is in the year 2015, so a natural split would be use everything up to 2015–01–01 for training, and everything after for testing. This will help us answer the first question of whether or not it is possible to predict the position of a hurricane using our available data.
  2. To answer the second question we will need to apply several different machine learning algorithms to create several different models and assess each model in turn to find the better performing (or best “fit”). We will be using the most excellent caret package that comes bundled with support for a great many algorithms. We’ll loop over a few, log the results, then pick our winner based on some measure of accuracy.

On to the code.

Creating Machine Learning Models

Having established our process, let’s get started by walking through some R code. We start by reading some files from disk, the first is the merged dataset, the second is a list of algorithms from the caret package.

# Read data from disk
storms_filename <- "in/stormsr.csv"
algo_filename <- "in/regressors.csv"

Let’s create our training and testing set by splitting the data at the date 2015–01–01.

# SPLIT TRAINING AND TESTING DATASETS ####
# Get the cut-off date for training vs testing data
testStartDate <- paste(as.character(year(max(data$date))),
  "01-01", sep = "-")

# Now get the testing dataset
testing <- subset(data, data$date >= testStartDate)

# Conversely get the training dataset
training <- subset(data, data$date < testStartDate)

Now we need formulas to feed into the algorithms — one for predicting latitude and another for longitude. Notice that the formula includes characteristics of storms (prefix of “st_”) and characteristics of the moon (prefixes of “mi_” and “mp_”). This is indicating to the algorithms to create models to predict latitude and longitude of storms using known values from the data about storms and known values about the moon.

# Create a formula
formula_lat <- lat ~ st_day +
  st_month +
  long +
  st_status +
  st_category +
  st_wind +
  st_pressure +
  st_ts_diameter +
  st_hu_diameter +
  mi_fraction +
  mi_phase +
  mi_angle +
  mp_altitude +
  mp_azimuth +
  mp_distance +
  mp_parallacticangle
  
# Create a formula
formula_long <- long ~ st_day +
  st_month +
  lat +
  st_status +
  st_category +
  st_wind +
  st_pressure +
  st_ts_diameter +
  st_hu_diameter +
  mi_fraction +
  mi_phase +
  mi_angle +
  mp_altitude +
  mp_azimuth +
  mp_distance +
  mp_parallacticangle

The next step is to create models. Note as well that we’re logging the duration of each training command using Sys.time(). This will help us to determine which algorithm (shown as regressor here) is the fastest. Bearing in mind that speed may not necessarily have any relationship with accuracy.

# Train model for predicting latitude and log duration  
model_lat_start_time <- Sys.time()
model_lat <- train(formula_lat, data = training,
  method = regressor,
  trControl = ctrl )
model_lat_endtime <- Sys.time()  
model_lat_timetaken <- model_lat_endtime - model_lat_start_time
  
# Train model for predicting longitude and log duration  
model_long_start_time <- Sys.time()  
model_long <- train(formula_long, data = training,
  method = regressor,
  trControl = ctrl )
model_long_endtime <- Sys.time()    
model_long_timetaken <- model_long_endtime - model_long_start_time

Performing Predictions

Now that we have applied our training data to algorithms to create models we’ll next use our models to perform predictions against our testing day (dates greater than 2015–01–01) based on the formulas above. We’ll perform predictions for latitude and longitude separately.

# Perform prediction for latitudes
  predictions_lat <- predict(model_lat,
    newdata = testing_lat)
  
# Perform prediction for longitudes
  predictions_long <- predict(model_long,
    newdata = testing_long)

We will create a model and perform predictions for each algorithm found in the regressor.csv file we read from disk earlier. Each resulting prediction will be logged to disk for the next step.

Finding the Best Results

Choosing the right algorithm to power your machine learning model can be a complex affair. Different algorithms have different use cases, some are applicable to regression problems, some classification, and some are capable of both. Algorithms are also tuned in different ways and come with different tuning parameters. Algorithms offer different benefits in terms of speed versus accuracy.

Further, how the performance of an algorithm is measured is also important. Regressors and classifiers are measured very differently. There are theoretical measurements such as MAE or RMSE for regressors, and AUC or ROC for classifiers. Then there are real world measurements against regressor prediction performance in the wild such as residuals. Residuals are the difference between a prediction and the actual observed value in the real world. For example, if we predicted that the latitude of Hurricane Joaquin would be 24.37 degrees on 2015–10–01, but the actual observed latitude was 25.37 degrees then the residual would be 1 degree. That would be the error of our prediction, that is, its real world bottom-line performance that end users care about.

So, to choose the best performing algorithm we will be choosing those predictions with the lowest residuals for predictions of latitude and longitude. The following steps detail how this is done.

First, we obtain residuals. Notice that the values are made absolute with the abs function. Absolute numbers are simply values without regard for them being negative or positive, the sign is removed.

# Get residuals for latitude and longitude
predictions <- cbind(predictions, abs(predictions$lat - 
  predictions$predictions_lat))
predictions <- cbind(predictions, abs(predictions$long - 
  predictions$predictions_long))
  
names(predictions) [21] <- "residuals_lat"
names(predictions) [22] <- "residuals_long"

Now we compound the residuals into a single value by multiplying them.

# Gather residuals into a single column
predictions <- cbind(predictions,
  predictions$residuals_lat * predictions$residuals_long)
  
# Rename column as appropriate
names(predictions) [23] <- "residuals_stacked"

Now get the minimum residuals for the compounded value of latitude and longitude by date. That is, get the best predictions for both latitude and longitude that day, for that storm.

# Get the minimum residuals by date
min_residuals <- aggregate(predictions$residuals_stacked, 
  list(predictions$date), min)
  
# Rename column as appropriate
names(min_residuals) [2] <- "residuals_stacked"

Finally, merge the best residuals with our predictions data frame to get a full set of columns, including the best performing algorithms.

# Find rows that match the minimum residuals
predictions <- merge(predictions, min_residuals, 
  by = "residuals_stacked")

# Remove extraneous columns
predictions <- subset(predictions, select = -c(Group.1))

Our final data frame looks like this.

> predictions %>% select(date, st_name, lat, long, predictions_lat, 
    predictions_long, regressor, residuals_stacked)        date st_name  lat  long predictions_lat predictions_long   regressor residuals_stacked
1 2015-09-30 Joaquin 25.4 -71.8        25.40540        -73.97837         gam       0.011753685
2 2015-10-01 Joaquin 23.1 -73.7        23.06251        -74.10402      ranger       0.015146710
3 2015-10-02 Joaquin 23.6 -74.8        23.60023        -71.00883       ridge       0.000865186
4 2015-10-03 Joaquin 25.4 -72.6        25.39637        -68.43249         dnn       0.015148261
5 2015-10-04 Joaquin 28.9 -68.3        27.70000        -68.30000         qrf       0.000000000
6 2015-10-05 Joaquin 32.6 -66.0        32.59912        -70.88011    bagEarth       0.004306631
7 2015-10-06 Joaquin 37.9 -60.4        37.02775        -60.43105 bagEarthGCV       0.027079906
8 2015-10-07 Joaquin 40.3 -51.5        40.28145        -53.14296   xgbLinear       0.030473250

Observations

For clarity, let’s focus our observations on Hurricane Joaquin as presented above. We note the following:

  1. It is possible to now answer our first question — we can predict, to some measurable accuracy, the path of a hurricane. We can observe the differences between lat and predictions_lat, and long and predictions_long respectively. We can also observe the compounded, or stacked, residuals.
  2. Most importantly, we were only able to get these results by applying multiple algorithms, of the eight (8) rows available, there are eight (8) different algorithms that provide the best prediction for Hurricane Joaquin on that day. This further implies that no single algorithm was optimal to this prediction problem. This makes sense since we found no strong correlations in our data analysis. Machine learning algorithms tend to perform better when meaningful correlations exist in the data.
  3. Finally, we did not perform any feature engineering in this exercise. It’s possible that if we did that pre-work we might have seen a prevalent algorithm surfacing to give optimal results.

Let’s attach the table above to a visualization using leaflet. The circles show predictions, while the markers show the actual positions.

Conclusion

We were ultimately able to answer both questions of interest. We can predict the path of a hurricane using the combined historical storm and moon data, however, it was done using somewhat unconventional means. The predictions were only possible by harvesting the best performing algorithm for each day for each storm. Ensemble approaches as this are not terribly uncommon but needless to say are more difficult to create and to operate. This is especially true in public cloud ecosystems where customers oftentimes pay by the hour of computing time. It may not be feasible to operate dozens of algorithms to pick single best performing results.

Having said that, we already knew the data was not highly correlated so this degree of accuracy at all is still good performance. If this were a more typical dataset (not moon versus storm) then we could have expected to see good, even stellar, performance from a single algorithm especially if we had performed feature engineering and then performed tuning.

Thank you for reading.

Originally published at https://solutioned.com on April 30, 2020.

]
StoryTitle: Machine Learning: Predicting the Path of Storms

StoryHTML:
[

Why you Should Stop Using the ROC Curve

The most popular metric may not be as meaningful as you think

Samuele Mazzanti
Follow
Apr 30 · 13 min read

When I started working as a data scientist, I used to use the ROC-curve to measure the goodness of a model. After all, this is the standard. Then, one day, a more experienced colleague told me:

“You should stop using the ROC-curve, you should use Average-Precision instead.”

On the spot, I didn’t think much about that phrase. I just followed my colleague’s advice. After all, he was very experienced, and I was a rookie. For sure, he must have known better than I did.

However, after some time, I started wondering if there exists a compelling way to prove whether and why one metric is better than the other.

Why is this relevant? Because, when we rely on a metric — such as ROC-Area or Average-Precision — we are assuming that the many facets of a model performance can be enclosed in a single number. At the end of the day, that number is all that matters. For this reason, we need to make sure that we are choosing wisely.

This post is the story of how I finally found evidence that my colleague was right.

0. A quick refresher… ROC and Average-Precision

If you are already confident with concepts such as Prevalence, ROC curve and Precision-Recall curve, you can skip this paragraph and go safely to Paragraph 1.

In this post, we will focus on 2-class classification problems. These are the most common problems in machine learning and are pretty general, since also regression problems and n-class problems can be traced back to this category, but not vice versa.

In a 2-class classification problem, we have some observations and we wish to create a model able to assign them to one of two classes (positives and negatives). For instance, in fraud detection, we may want to classify some financial transactions in positives (frauds) and negatives (non-frauds).

We will need some glossary to go on:

  • n: number of observations;
  • n_positives: number of positives;
  • n_negatives: number of negatives;
  • prevalence: n_positives / n;
  • n_predicted_positives: number of observations that the model has classified as positives;
  • n_true_positives: number of observations that the model has correctly classified as positives;
  • n_false_positives: number of observations that the model has mistakenly classified as positives;
  • precision: n_true_positives / n_predicted_positives;
  • recall: n_true_positives / n_positives;
  • false_positive_rate: n_false_positives / n_negatives;
  • roc_curve: set of all possible pairs (false_positive_rate, recall) for a given model, depending on probability thresholds;
  • precision_recall_curve: set of all possible pairs (precision, recall) for a given model, depending on probability thresholds;
  • roc_area: area under the roc_curve;
  • average_precision: area under the precision_recall_curve.

Given a model, this is how its ROC curve and Precision-Recall curve would look like:

These curves’ areas (i.e. integrals) — named respectively ROC-Area and Average-Precision — have some useful properties:

  • They are bounded to be between 0 and 1.
  • 0 means worst possible classification, 1 means best possible classification. So, the higher the better.
  • A random classification would score .5 for ROC-Area, while it would be equal to prevalence for Average-Precision.

For these reasons, ROC-Area and Average-Precision are usually employed as measures of goodness of a model.

This Paragraph was just basic CliffsNotes. If you wish to deepen these concepts, you may read these articles: “Understanding AUC-ROC Curve” by Sarang Narkhede and “Beyond Accuracy: Precision and Recall” by Will Koehrsen.

1. A need for generalization… (a.k.a. looking for the model-space)

Paragraph 1 and 2 are a bit theoretical. So if you wish to jump to Paragraph 3, you will be forgiven. But if you stick with me, you will be entitled to the nerd medal.

When I decided that I wished to figure out how ROC-Area and Average-Precision differ, I realized that I needed to make it general. In fact, it would have been useless to focus on a single model. If I did so, I would just have two numbers to compare: a ROC-Area and an Average-Precision. Clearly, it’s not enough to draw conclusions.

The procedure that I had in mind was the following:

  1. select a classification problem (a real-sized problem, not a toy one);
  2. generate n differently perfoming models (where n is large enough, like thousands) ensuring that they cover a wide range of performances;
  3. compute ROC-Area and Average-Precision for each of those n models,
  4. compare the n ROC-Areas and the n Average-Precisions to see if I can assess once and for all whether one metric is preferable to the other.

I am sure that you spotted the hitch in my plan. The 2nd point. Indeed, how do you generate thousands of different models? And — most of all — how do you ensure that they perform in a “sufficiently” different way? I was stuck there. Until I started playing with this idea:

Given a problem, is there a way to represent all the possible predictive models associated with it? In other words, is there a way to represent a “model-space”, i.e. a set of all the possible models for that problem?

In order to answer this question, let’s take a small problem: 4 observations, 2 of which are positives.

If you think about it, the actual values assumed by the predicted probabilities are irrelevant. After all, the outcome of any predictive model is a ranking of the observations.

For example, let’s say we have 2 models and the following predicted probabilities:

  • Model 1 predictions: [.6, .1, .9, .4],
  • Model 2 predictions: [.99, .8, .999, .9].

Model 1 and Model 2 are basically equivalent (disregarding calibration). In fact, in both models the observations are ranked the same: the 3rd observation is the riskier, followed by the 1st, then the 4th, and finally the 2nd.

Thus, once that predicted probabilities are sorted — no matter their actual value — all the possible models will necessarily fall into one of these 6 cases:

where white and black tiles represent respectively the negatives and the positives.

Therefore, the number of all possible models is simply the number of all the possible permutations of positives and negatives. In Combinatorics, this is called “permutations with repetitions”.

Having n elements in total, n_positives of which are repeated (because they are all ones) and n_negatives of which are repeated (because they are all zeroes), the number of possible permutations is n! / n_positives! / n_negatives!. Indeed, in our dummy example, we have 4! / 2! / 2! = 6 possible models. If you wish to understand how I got to this formula take a look at this nice explanation: “Permutations with Repetition”.

This particular formula, i.e. a! / b! / c! (where a, b and c are non-negative integers and a = b + c) is called binomial coefficient and it comes up often in maths (for instance, the binomial distribution is named after it)

So, to be more incisive we may say that:

The number of models existing in the model-space is given by the binomial coefficient of positives and negatives.

Despite this being an interesting result, it soon becomes unusable once the number of observations increases. For instance, for 10,000 observations and 100 positives we would have something like 6 * 10 ^ 241 possible models!

Needless to say, I could not compute ROC-Area and Average-Precision for some 6 * 10 ^ 241 models. So I had to abandon the idea of working with the full model-space.

2. But I didn’t want to give up… (a.k.a. the reduced model-space)

Then, I had to find a smarter way than just listing all the possible models existing in the model-space. This meant that I had to settle for a smaller — or “reduced” — model-space. Which is fine, as far as the reduced model-space is able to summarize the original model-space.

Ok, but how could I achieve it? I mean, getting the full model-space is easy: you just have to enumerate all the permutations of positives and negatives. But how to obtain a reduced-model-space? There is no recipe for this.

Let’s take again a small example: 10 observations, 4 of which are positives. As we know, the full model-space shall consist of 10! / 4! / 6! = 210 models. So, the goal is to find n models (with n much smaller than 210) such that they represent a “gradation” of different performances.

How to achieve that? After some trials, I came out with an idea.

These 7 models actually meet our requirements because:

  • 7 is much less than 210,
  • these models’ performances are perfectly “nuanced” from random (.5 ROC-Area) to best (ROC-Area equal to 1). Note that we can safely disregard models that do worse than random, because in practice they don’t exist.

Now, can you guess the pattern I’ve used to produce these combinations?

I’ve obtained this through a loop going from 0 to n_negatives (in this case, from 0 to 6). At each iteration:

  • positives are not allowed to be placed before a certain position, given by the value of the iterator (which goes from 0 to n_negatives);
  • after this position, positives are placed as equidistantly as possible (in order to create a sort of “average” random placing)

In this way, as the iterator increases, positives are “pushed” more and more to the highest probabilities, which means a progressively better model. At the last iteration, all the positives correspond exactly to the highest probabilities, which means that we have reached the best possible model. Through this procedure, we get a “condensed” model-space, a faithful although smaller reproduction of the full model-space.

This is a very convenient trick, because it dramatically reduces the number of models that we need to account for, from a crazy n! / n_positives! / n_negatives! to just n_negatives + 1. In this simple case, from 210 to 7. But the gain will be bigger and bigger as n grows.

If you want to take a look at the Python implementation of the algorithm, you can find it in my Github.

This simple algorithm makes the job feasible for all the realistic-sized classification problems! For instance, for a 1-million-observations, 10,000-positives problem, the reduced model-space contains “just” 990,001 models.

Mission accomplished!

So we can move on to the fun part, but not before I keep my promise…

3. Now the fun part… (a.k.a. a data scientist at the gym)

If you made it through Paragraphs 1 and 2, you have deserved all my appreciation. If you did not, don’t worry: here comes the fun (and relevant) part.

In Paragraphs 1 and 2, we have found a way to automatically generate many different models and to ensure that they perform differently, exploring all the possible nuances between two extremes: the random model and the perfect (theoretical) model. This is what we have called the “reduced” model-space.

Now, it’s time to do what we are really interested in: comparing ROC-Area and Average-Precision of the models and try to understand how they behave.

Let’s take a classification problem with:

  • n: 11,111
  • prevalence: 10 % (which means n_positives: 1,111 and n_negatives: 10,000)

Then, we can obtain the reduced model-space with the algorithm described in Paragraph 2. In this case, we will obtain 10,001 models, which are numbered from 0 (random) to 10,000 (best possible). For each model, ROC-Area and Average-Precision have been computed.

This is the result:

When I first saw this plot, I had one of those “Aha” moments.

My colleague was right!

While ROC-Area has a linear behavior, Average-Precision has an exponential behavior. The exponential behavior is a lot more realistic than the linear behavior. Why? If you ever went to the gym, you already know.

Say you are out of training and you decide you want to get fit for the summer. You get your gym membership. On the first day, you can bench-press 50 kg. Then, after three months of hard workout, you get to 100 kg. Amazing! Isn’t it?

But I’ll give you bad news: three months later, you won’t be able to bench-press 150 kg. In other words, your advances at bench-press are not linear.

That’s exactly what happens with machine learning. Getting a good model is relatively simple, getting a very good model is extremely hard.

And this is also what happens with Average-Precision. Getting a good Average-Precision is relatively simple, getting a very good Average-Precision is extremely hard.

4. I don’t see how this is useful… (a.k.a. how do I explain it to my boss?)

The bench-press metaphore is reflected by the behavior of Average-Precision. And this is even more true when the problem is harder. Indeed, let’s see how Average-Precision changes for different values of prevalence.

As you see, with a prevalence of 50%, Average-Precision is very much alike to ROC-Area. But then, the lower the prevalence, the “more exponential” is the learning curve. It’s intuitive. Having a very low prevalence is like — as they say — trying to find a needle in a haystack. The larger the haystack, the harder the problem. As a consequence, it’s harder and harder to get to a high level of Average-Precision.

This is exactly the point of using Average-Precision rather than ROC-Area. Average-Precision is more realistic and gives you a fair idea of how your model is actually performing.

Are you still not convinced? Let’s go back to the example we have already seen in Paragraph 3, the 10% prevalence case.

Imagine we have trained 3 models and we want to compare them based on their performances on some test data. Inside the brackets, we show the quantile of each model inside the model-space, where 0% is random and 100% is the best possible (theoretical) model. These are the results:

  • Logistic-Regression (60%),
  • plain Gradient-Boosting algorithm (80%),
  • the same Gradient-Boosting algorithm with some smart hyperparameter optimization (87%).

So far, no wonder: optimized Gradient-Boosting did better than plain Gradient-Boosting which in turn did better than Logistic-Regression. But the point is:

How better?

And trust me: this is not philosophy. In a Kaggle challenge, you can choose either Average-Precision or ROC-Area: it makes no difference, because higher is better, without further question.

But in real life, answering to the question “how much is model A better than model B?” is crucial. For instance:

Is it worth to spend 10 hours in hyperparameter optimization to get 1% more in ROC-Area? And to get 1% more in Average-Precision?

Being able to answer these questions is one of the most important skills of a data scientist. And this is why the distinction between Average-Precision and ROC-Area is so relevant.

Indeed, let’s see where the 3 models would be placed, based on their percentile:

Let’s focus on ROC-Area first (left plot). With Logistic-Regression you reach 80% ROC-Area, which is pretty good. With Gradient-Boosting you can get to 90%, which is great. Then, after— let’s say — 10 hours of hyperparameter optimization, you can hit 93% ROC Area with the optimized Gradient-Boosting. At this point, your boss may legitimately ask you: “Is this really necessary? 10 hours to gain a 3% in ROC Area? Why don’t we just settle for 90%?” Your boss has made a good point.

Moving from 90% to 93% in ROC-Area doesn’t seem a big deal. Why should we bother?

Well, if you look at Average-Precision you get a totally different picture. By moving from the unoptimized Gradient-Boosting to the optimized one, you get an astounding 10% more in Average-Precision: you are increasing Average-Precision by almost one third, from 36% to 46%!

If this was an antifraud model, it would mean that out of 100 transactions tagged as potential frauds, the optimized Gradient-Boosting would correctly guess on average 10 frauds more than the plain Gradient-Boosting.

It doesn’t take a PhD in machine learning to realize this makes a huge difference.

5. Wrap-up

In this article, we have found out a couple of useful things about 2-class classification problems. In particular, we have:

  • discovered that the dimension of the model-space (i.e. the set of all possible models for a given problem) is given by the binomial coefficient: n! / n_positives! / n_negatives!;
  • found an algorithm for obtaining a smaller space, called the “reduced” model-space, which is a faithful miniature of the full model-space. This is extremely useful because it allows to work with an affordable number of models: just n_negatives + 1;
  • compared ROC-Area and Average-Precision and realized that the value of ROC-Area increases linearly as the quality of the model improves, whereas Average-Precision grows exponentially;
  • noticed how the value of ROC-Area can be misleading and can cause us sometimes to overestimate and sometimes to underestimate the actual performance of a model. The behavior of Average-Precision is more expressive in getting a flavour of how the model is doing, because it is more sensible in distinguishing between a good and a very good model. Moreover, it is directly linked to precision: an indicator which is human-understandable.

Thank you for reading! I hope you found this post useful.

I appreciate feedback and constructive criticism. If you want to talk about this article or other related topics, you can text me at my Linkedin contact.

Note: all the Python code used for obtaining the previous plots — including the algorithm for building the reduced model-space — can be found here: https://github.com/smazzanti/why_you_should_stop_using_the_roc_curve

]
StoryTitle: Why you Should Stop Using the ROC Curve

StoryHTML:
[

What Does a DQN Think?

A brief visualization of how a DQN chooses to play Breakout

Sebastian Theiler
Apr 30 · 6 min read

In the last article, we explored how we could build a DQN to score 350+. As a quick recap, here is a short clip of that DQN playing:

The DQN is certainly playing well, but in a given situation, is it possible to tell why the DQN took the move it did?

For a game as simple as Breakout, it isn’t too tricky. If the ball is headed down-left, the agent better move left.

But what about an environment like Montezuma’s Revenge? Or StarCraft, DOTA, maybe even an RL agent in the real world? Can we understand how agents in those environments make their decisions? And if we can’t, can we trust these agents to make reliable decisions in the real world?

To try and answer some of these questions, I set out to build a visualization of what our DQN has learned, and what’s going on inside its head as it makes decisions.

Pyglet

This visualizer is built in Pyglet. Pyglet is an incredibly efficient and powerful library for visual applications, building on top of OpenGL graphics, while also introducing features for joysticks and audio.

Although claiming to be “easy to use,” I’ve had quite a few issues with Pyglet, and even things as simple as drawing a rectangle require inputting each individual vertex. Often times when the code should have raised an error, Pyglet would simply ignore that code. Anyway, Pyglet’s sheer power and efficiency compensate for most of its issues.

If you don’t have Pyglet installed already (it should come pre-installed with Gym), you can install it with:

pip3 install pyglet

I will not be explaining code bit-by-bit in this article, as in all honesty, Pyglet is well out of my area of expertise and the code I’ve written is far from perfect. Instead, the code for the visualizations in this article will be available on my GitHub, here.

Base Screen

First things first, we want to be able to see the regular screen our agent is playing on. So far, the following visualization is no different than watching the agent play with the standard visualize function in Gym.

What the Agent Sees

Next, let’s see how the agent sees the game. If you remember, we are passing in 4 stacked frames to the agent so that it can understand movement. In our visualization, the frame furthest to the left will be the furthest back in time.

Seeing what the game looked like through the agent’s eyes actually helped build the original DQN. When I was building it, I didn’t know that BreakoutDeterministic-v4 automatically skipped 4 frames and I was implementing it manually. This stacked on top of the automatic frame skip, and my agent ended up seeing only 1 in every 16 frames — way too little! If I didn’t have access to what the agent was seeing, I may have never realized this.

OpenAI had a similar experience training a DQN to play Seaquest. Gray-scaling the scene actually made some objects invisible and as a result the DQN performed poorly:

Visualizing the Q-Values

Now let’s visualize the Q-Values. We will do this in 4 separate boxes, one for each action. The lighter a box is, the higher the Q-Value is for that action. Note, the Q-Values are normalized relative to each other.

Expected Value Over Time

Here’s where things start to get interesting. Now we are going to visualize the expected value over time:

A few interesting things are happening here. Most obviously, the expected value continually rises as the ball nears the ‘bricks’ at the top of the screen. After the ball bounces back down off the bricks, the expected value suddenly shoots down. Furthermore, the average expected value continually rises until the agent can successfully get the ball on top of the bricks, after that the expected reward falls, likely as there are less bricks to score from.

These are both good signs, as it shows that the DQN has an understanding of what is actually happening in Breakout, and it can make simple long-term plans with that reasoning.

Attention Heatmap

The final, and in my opinion most interesting, bit of visualization I’d like to take a look at is attention heatmaps. Areas shaded dark red are where the agent pays the most attention to, while the agent pays little attention to blue-shaded areas.

From this, we can tell that nearly everything the agent cares about is between the paddle and the bricks. The agent doesn’t care much about what is going on within, and above the bricks, presumably since the ball’s behavior is too random there. As the agent clears out more bricks, it starts to pay more attention to the brick and above-brick area.

It’s interesting that the agent doesn’t pay too much attention to the paddle itself. This seems to suggest that it has some intuitive understanding of where the paddle should be in a given state (although it has no direct internal state).

If you have any other explanations for this, or for why there seems to be a spot of disinterest following the ball, I’d love to hear them!

This article by Areeb Gani is an excellent introduction to “Grad-CAM,” which is how the heatmaps were built. If you’re interested, here is the Grad-CAM paper.

Visualizing the Replay Buffer

If you’ve read Mnih et al. 2015, you might remember this captivating image:

Each tiny little dot in that image is a unique state. The more red the dot is, the higher expected value in that state.

This version of the visualization will:

  • Sample 500–1000 states from the agent’s replay buffer
  • For each state, calculate the expected value
  • For each state, take the activations of units in an intermediate layer to get a 512-unit vector
  • Use PCA to translate those vectors into 2D space
  • Visualize those PCA-encoded vectors on a scatterplot, colored according to the expected value. Some of the points will be annotated with what that frame looks like to the agent.

The result turns out like this:

Conclusion

Breakout is a simple game, but we can scale up and build upon the techniques we used here for much more sophisticated algorithms playing much more complicated games.

As we implement new algorithms such as A3C and curiosity driven learning in this series on RL, I hope to do just that with this visualizer — build upon it and hopefully get some insights about how our RL agents work in the process.

If we can’t explain the actions of a DQN playing Breakout, how can we expect to understand RL models in the real world?

And as always, until next time,

Happy coding!

The source-code for this article is available on my GitHub, here.

Note: the GIFs and videos in this article were sped-up. They will most likely run significantly slower in real time.

]
StoryTitle: What Does a DQN Think?

Serendipity: Accuracy’s unpopular best friend in Recommender Systems

What I learned about measuring diversity, novelty, surprise, and serendipity from 10+ papers.

Eugene Yan
Follow
Apr 30 · 10 min read

Is accuracy the only metric that matters in recommendation systems?

Maybe not.

Imagine you started using Spotify to listen to your favourite artiste. If Spotify only recommended music from that artiste, would it be accurate? Yes. Would you like those recommendations? Probably at the start, but you would get bored quickly.

What you want is for a recommender system to (pleasantly) surprise you. That is the concept of serendipity.

Why are accuracy (aka relevance) metrics more commonly discussed and applied then?

I suspect it’s due to a combination of the following:

  • Accuracy metrics (e.g., NDCG, MAP, AUC, recall@n) are widely available in libraries (e.g., sklearn, SparkML); implementations for serendipity metrics are scarce.
  • Accuracy metrics are more commonly taught in classes, to significant depth; serendipity metrics are mostly touch-and-go.
  • Accuracy metrics are universally adopted in literature; the jury’s still out on formula for serendipity metrics.
  • During offline evaluation, it is easier to improve accuracy metrics.
  • In production, accuracy metrics have a stronger correlation with (short-term) recommender performance (i.e., click-through-rate, conversion).

Nonetheless, if you’re keen to learn about an alternative approach to evaluating recommender systems (based on what I gleaned from 10+ papers), read on.

Why serendipity?

It keeps your customers interested.

In the earlier example, the music recommender was very accurate — it only recommended music from artistes you liked and previously listened to. A model solely focused on accuracy would do very well in offline evaluation (of the latest week of data).

But in the real world, it would suck. It would recommend very similar music daily. Users would get bored soon.

People intrinsically enjoy variety and discovering things such as new artistes, genres, communities, etc. Helping users discover new products keeps them interested.

It’s good for business.

Keeping customer utility high is important. But besides customer utility, you also need to care about assortment health and seller health.

From an e-commerce perspective, poor assortment health means a small percentage of products, categories, or sellers (5%) get a disproportionately large portion of sales and revenue (95%). If those top sellers decide to move to a competitor platform, it’s gonna hurt. The same would happen if a top-selling product stops being available (e.g., out of stock, banned, cease production).

Introducing serendipity (and the associated metrics of diversity and novelty) help recommend more products from the long-tail of assortment. This distributes sales more evenly, reducing dependency and risk on the minority of products and sellers.

As a plus, you get to expose long-tail and cold-start products to customers. This helps gather training data which you can use to improve your recommender. It’s a virtuous cycle.

How to measure serendipity?

“If you can’t measure it, you can’t improve it” — Peter Drucker

Unfortunately, there’s no industry agreed-upon standard to measure serendipity. Unlike relevance metrics such as non-discounted cumulative gain (NDCG), mean average precision (MAP), recall, precision, etc.

To gain a better understanding of how to measure serendipity, I went through 10+ papers on serendipity in recommender systems. Here’s a summary of the key metrics and the various ways to measure them.

Diversity

Diversity measures how narrow or wide the spectrum of recommended products are. A recommender that only recommends the music of one artiste is pretty narrow; one that recommends across multiple artistes is more diverse.

There are two main ways of measuring diversity — based on item and based on users.

Measuring diversity based on item is straightforward. We can do this based on metadata of the recommended items:

  • How many different categories/genres?
  • How many different artistes/authors/sellers?
  • What is the kurtosis (“tailness”) of the price distribution?
  • How different (i.e., distant) are the product embeddings?

Another approach is measuring diversity based on existing customers. For each item in the recommended set, who has consumed it? If the items have a relatively large proportion of common users, the recommended items are likely very similar.

One way to measure this is cosine similarity (Ziegler et al., 2004). For two products, what’s the proportion of common users?

This can then be extended to the set of recommended items.

(Note: Want to view the original latex equations? They’re available here.)

Novelty

Novelty measures how new, original, or unusual the recommendations are for the user.

In general, recommendations will mostly consist of popular items because (i) popular items have more data and (ii) popular items do well in offline and online evaluations.

However, if an item is popular or top-selling, a user would already have been exposed to it. This could happen via your “top-selling” or “trending” banners, social media, or a user’s relationships (i.e., family, friends, co-workers). Therefore, it makes sense to tweak a recommender for novelty to reduce the number of popular items it recommends.

The common way I’ve seen papers measure novelty is to compare a user’s recommended items to the population. How often does a user’s recommendations occur in the rest of the population’s recommendations? There are two forms of measuring this (Zhang et al 2011, Vargas & Castells, 2011):

In both equations, the numerator counts the number of users who were recommended the item. The denominator counts the total number of users. In both cases, if all users were recommended the item, then novelty would be zero.

Some papers measure novelty this way, comparing a user’s recommendations against the population’s recommendations. I’m not sure if this is the best approach to measure novelty — how does it matter to the user what recommendations other people receive?

If a user is the only person recommended a product (e.g., a Harry Potter book), novelty — as measured above — would be close to maximum.

But the rest of the population might already have purchased/read the book (and thus not be recommended it). If everyone around the user has bought, read, or talked about the product — is the recommended product still novel to the user?

A better measure of novelty is to consider the population’s interactions (e.g., purchases, clicks) instead of recommendations. This reflects how likely the user has been exposed to the product based on the population historical engagement.

What if we want to measure novelty specific to a user? Most literature refers to that as unexpectedness or surprise.

Unexpectedness (aka surprise)

One measure of unexpectedness is to compare a user’s new recommendations (from an updated recommender) against previous recommendations. This measures “how much surprise are we introducing with this serendipity feature”. It’s useful for tracking incremental improvements on recommendation systems.

Another approach is to compare recommendations relative to the user’s historical item interaction. This measures “how surprising are these recommendations given what the user previously bought/clicked on”. I believe this is a better way to operationalise surprise.

One way to measure this is via point-wise mutual information (PMI). PMI indicates how similar two items are based on the number of users who have purchased both items and each item separately (similar to measuring diversity based on users).

p(i) is the probability of any user consuming item I, while p(i, j) is the probability of a user consuming both. PMI ranges from -1 to 1, where -1 indicates that the two items are never consumed together.

Another approach is to consider some distance metric (e.g., cosine similarity). We compute cosine similarity between a user’s recommended items (I) and historical item interactions (H). Lower cosine similarity indicates higher unexpectedness.

Serendipity

Serendipity is measured as unexpectedness multiplied by relevance, where relevance is 1 if the recommended item is interacted with (e.g., purchase, click) and 0 otherwise. For a recommended item (i), we only consider unexpectedness if the user interacted with i.

To get overall serendipity, we average over all users (U) and all recommended items (I).

It seems straightforward to implement this in code but in reality, it’s a tricky matter. If your recommender system is deliberately introducing long-tail and cold-start products, you can expect the relevance metric to perform poorly in offline evaluations. Nonetheless, the recommendations might still be useful to customers and perform well in an A/B test.

(In a previous project where I deliberately introduced cold-start products in a product ranking system, the offline evaluation metrics were bad and we expected conversion to drop a bit. To our surprise, we actually saw conversion improve during the A/B test.)

So take offline evaluation metrics of serendipity (and relevance) with a pinch of salt. Use them to compare between multiple recommenders but don’t let them dissuade you from starting an A/B test.

Putting it all together

Whew! That was a lot of material and formula. How do I know which to use and when?

Here are some basic guidelines:

Diversity

  • Do you care about how different the recommended items look? If so, measure diversity based on item features.
  • Do you care about the cross-pollination of communities and user groups (e.g., Facebook group and meet-up group recommendations)? If so, consider diversity based on users.

Novelty

  • Do you want a user’s recommendations to be different from what their friends get? If so, compare between a user’s and population’s recommendations.
  • Do you want a user’s recommendations to be novel relative to historical public interaction? If so, compare a user’s recommendations vs the population’s past purchase/clicks.

Unexpectedness

  • Do you want to surprise users with recommendations that are different from what they are used to? If so, compare between a user’s new and previous recommendations.
  • Do you want to surprise users with recommendations that are different from the products they have previously purchased? If so, compare between a user’s recommendations to their past purchase.

Conclusion

Measuring serendipity and her cousin metrics isn’t easy or straightforward. You can’t simply import them from a library (e.g., sklearn, SparkML), unlike NDCG, MAP, etc.

Nevertheless, tracking serendipity is useful for a successful long-term recommendation strategy. Too much focus on accuracy leads to boring recommendations, bored users, poor assortment health, and suboptimal business.

What other approaches do you use to evaluate recommendation engines? Reach out via Twitter (@eugeneyan) or share in the comments below!

References

Adomavicius, G., & Kwon, Y. (2011, October). Maximizing aggregate recommendation diversity: A graph-theoretic approach. In Proc. of the 1st International Workshop on Novelty and Diversity in Recommender Systems (DiveRS 2011) (pp. 3–10).

Celma, Ò., & Herrera, P. (2008, October). A new approach to evaluating novel recommendations. In Proceedings of the 2008 ACM conference on Recommender systems (pp. 179–186).

Chen, L., Wang, N., Yang, Y., Yang, K., & Yuan, Q. (2019). User Validation of Recommendation Serendipity Metrics. arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.11431.

Ge, M., Delgado-Battenfeld, C., & Jannach, D. (2010, September). Beyond accuracy: evaluating recommender systems by coverage and serendipity. In Proceedings of the fourth ACM conference on Recommender systems (pp. 257–260).

Iaquinta, L., De Gemmis, M., Lops, P., Semeraro, G., Filannino, M., & Molino, P. (2008, September). Introducing serendipity in a content-based recommender system. In 2008 Eighth International Conference on Hybrid Intelligent Systems (pp. 168–173). IEEE.

Kotkov, D., Konstan, J. A., Zhao, Q., & Veijalainen, J. (2018, April). Investigating serendipity in recommender systems based on real user feedback. In Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM Symposium on Applied Computing (pp. 1341–1350).

Kotkov, D., Wang, S., & Veijalainen, J. (2016). A survey of serendipity in recommender systems. Knowledge-Based Systems, 111, 180–192.

Lee, K., & Lee, K. (2015). Escaping your comfort zone: A graph-based recommender system for finding novel recommendations among relevant items. Expert Systems with Applications, 42(10), 4851–4858.

Mourão, F., Fonseca, C., Araujo, C. S., & Meira Jr, W. (2011, October). The Oblivion Problem: Exploiting Forgotten Items to Improve Recommendation Diversity. In DiveRS@ RecSys (pp. 27–34).

Oku, K., & Hattori, F. (2011). Fusion-based Recommender System for Improving Serendipity. DiveRS@ RecSys, 816, 19–26.

Panagiotis, A., & Alexander, T. (2011). On unexpectedness in recommender systems: Or how to expect the unexpected. In Workshop on Novelty and Diversity in Recommender Systems, 2011.

Santini, S., & Castells, P. (2011). An evaluation of novelty and diversity based on fuzzy logic. In CEUR Workshop Proceedings. Pablo Castells.

Vargas, S., & Castells, P. (2011, October). Rank and relevance in novelty and diversity metrics for recommender systems. In Proceedings of the fifth ACM conference on Recommender systems (pp. 109–116).

Zhang, Y. C., Séaghdha, D. Ó., Quercia, D., & Jambor, T. (2012, February). Auralist: introducing serendipity into music recommendation. In Proceedings of the fifth ACM international conference on Web search and data mining (pp. 13–22).

Thanks to Xinyi Yang and Gabriel Chuan for reading drafts of this.

]
StoryTitle: Serendipity: Accuracy’s unpopular best friend in Recommender Systems

Google Colab: How does it compare to a GPU-enabled laptop?

Introduction to Colab, Runtimes, Performance Comparisons… and Gotchas

Dario Radečić
Follow
Apr 30 · 5 min read

If you haven’t been living under a rock, there’s a very high probability that you’ve used or at least heard of Google Colaboratory — a cloud-based notebook environment that lets you write, execute, and share code in Google Drive.

But how does it compare with Jupyter Lab that we are all used to and know in-depth? Stay tuned to find out.

Just in case you don’t know anything about Colab, here are a couple of bullets to get you right on track:

  • The equivalent of JupyterLab — with some tweaks
  • Hosted by Google — notebooks automatically saved to Google Drive
  • Free access to GPUs (Graphics Processing Unit) and TPUs (Tensor Processing Unit)
  • Made for Data Science — the vast majority of data science libraries are preinstalled

So just by looking at these bullets, it sounds like a sweet deal, but let’s leave that claim for the end— as only then will we be able to use data to make conclusions.

The article is structured as follows:

  1. Creating a Notebook
  2. Runtime Environments
  3. Performance Comparison
  4. The Verdict

So without further ado, let’s get started!

Creating a Notebook

This process can’t be any simpler — simply go to colab.research.google.com. If you are logged into your Google account a window like this should pop up:

You can now create a new notebook by clicking on the New Notebook button on the bottom right portion of the modal window. After a couple of seconds, you’ll be welcomed to a familiar-looking screen:

If you don’t like the default light theme you can change it easily. Just go to Tools — Settings, and in there this modal should pop up:

The theme is set to light by default, so change it to dark if you wish, and click on Save. I really like the dark theme, but the light one just goes better with the article so I’ll stick to it (sighs).

In the cell, you can now simply import any library you need and start working. Most of the libraries come preinstalled, so one thing less to worry about. To demonstrate, let’s import Numpy and do some quick array addition:

Great, nothing new here, but it still a valid way to verify that everything works properly.

Now, I highly doubt you’ll be using Colab to deal with Numpy (unless you’re working on a potato), so in the next section, we’ll briefly explore various runtimes you can use.

Runtime Environments

Colab is mostly used to handle GPU intensive tasks — like training deep learning models. And that’s the basic idea behind it— everybody can get access to a GPU or TPU.

So let’s quickly explore how to switch to GPU/TPU runtime. Simply go to the Runtime tab and select Change runtime type:

A modal window like this will pop up, and in here you can switch from None to something more suitable:

I’ve gone ahead and selected GPU. After a couple of seconds, GPU will be allocated to you if available. We can verify this with any deep learning library, I’ll use PyTorch:

Now, there’s no guarantee that you will get the same GPU as I did so keep that in mind.

Okay, you are now familiar with Google Colab, so in the next section, we’ll compare it’s performance to a stack of my laptops, but also to a CPU runtime of Google Colab.

Performance Comparison

To make a quick performance test, I decided to use the PyTorch library to train on the Fashion-MNIST dataset. The model has the following architecture:

So nothing special here, around 150K trainable parameters (weights and biases) that need to be optimized. Alongside Google Colab, I’ll also use three laptops I currently have in my possession:

  • Lenovo ThinkPad T480s: Intel i7–8550U @ 1.8 GHz, 16GB RAM
  • Lenovo Legion Y540: Intel i5–9300H @ 2.4 GHz, Nvidia GeForce 1650 4GB, 16GB RAM
  • MacBook Pro 2019 13": Intel i5-QC @ 1.4 GHz, 8GB RAM

One final note: model was trained on CPU for ThinkPad and MacBook Pro (obviously), while it was trained on GPU for the Lenovo Legion. On Google Colab I went with CPU runtime in the first notebook and with the GPU runtime in the second.

Let’s see a quick chart to compare training time:

And there you have it — Google Colab, a free service is faster than my GPU-enabled Lenovo Legion Laptop. For some reason, MacBook outperformed it, even though it has only quad-core 1.4GHz CPU. ThinkPad, as the most expensive device here performed the worst.

Now we are able to make a data-driven conclusion — let’s do so in the following section.

The Verdict

The toy Fashion-MNIST dataset is by no means representative enough to make bulletproof conclusions — as that would require a larger dataset and much more training cycles — but we can conclude that Google Colab can be a blessing if you don’t have a $3000 gaming PC.

There are some gotchas to it, like:

  • Runtime disconnection — the runtime will disconnect if the notebook is sitting idle for some time
  • Memory — it is possible to run out of memory
  • Dependence — there’s no guarantee that GPU or TPU will be available at the time you need it, so keep that in mind

Even with all the caveats, it is still pretty easy to recommend — at least by using it your PC won’t get warm — something of crucial importance for the upcoming summer months.

Thanks for reading.

]
StoryTitle: Google Colab: How does it compare to a GPU-enabled laptop?

StoryHTML:

The #paperoftheweek is “RelGAN: Multi-Domain Image-to-Image Translation via Relative Attributes”

brighter AI
Apr 30 · 3 min read

Multi-domain image-to-image translation methods usually take an image and some target attributes as inputs and generate an output image with the desired attributes. In the case of a facial image, we can manipulate such attributes as hair color, gender, age, and smile while keeping the identity and other attributes and background invariant. In this paper authors propose RelGAN, a relative-attribute-based method for multi-domain image-to-image translation.

Most existing target-attribute-based methods require a complete attribute representation to specify the target domain, even if only a subset of attributes is manipulated. In this case, the model does not know whether each attribute is required to change or not, thus it can over-emphasize some attributes. Authors overcome this limitation by using the relative attribute representation (−1, 0, 1), where each value corresponds to a desired action to an attribute: turn on (+1), turn off (−1), or unchanged (0).

Another limitation of previous methods is that these methods assume binary attributes and therefore are not designed for continuous attribute interpolation. A smooth and realistic interpolation is important because it enables fine-grained control over the strength of each attribute (e.g., the percentage of brown vs. blond hair color, or the degree of smile/happiness). The authors propose to use the interpolation coefficient in attribute representation.

RelGAN consists of a single generator and three discriminators, which are respectively responsible for guiding the generator to learn to generate (1) realistic images, (2) accurate translations in terms of the relative attributes, and (3) realistic interpolations. The generator is also trained using cycle-reconstruction and self-reconstruction losses. Figure 2 from the paper provides an overview of RelGAN.

Authors compare RelGAN with StarGAN and AttGAN, and show superior performance of RelGAN over these methods in terms of both visual quality and quantitative effectiveness. Figure 16 from paper demonstrates some of the facial attribute transfer results of RelGAN.

Abstract:

“Multi-domain image-to-image translation has gained increasing attention recently. Previous methods take an image and some target attributes as inputs and generate an output image with the desired attributes. However, such methods have two limitations. First, these methods assume binary-valued attributes and thus cannot yield satisfactory results for fine-grained control. Second, these methods require specifying the entire set of target attributes, even if most of the attributes would not be changed. To address these limitations, we propose RelGAN, a new method for multi-domain image-to-image translation. The key idea is to use relative attributes, which describes the desired change on selected attributes. Our method is capable of modifying images by changing particular attributes of interest in a continuous manner while preserving the other attributes. Experimental results demonstrate both the quantitative and qualitative effectiveness of our method on the tasks of facial attribute transfer and interpolation.”

Authors:

Po-Wei Wu, Yu-Jing Lin, Che-Han Chang, Edward Y. Chang, Shih-Wei Liao.

You can read the paper here and the code.

About the author

Elena Sukmanova, Deep Learning Researcher at brighter AI.

About brighter AI:

brighter AI has developed an innovative privacy solution for visual data: Deep Natural Anonymization. The solution replaces personally identifiable information such as faces and license plates with artificial objects, thereby enabling all AI and analytics use cases, e.g. self-driving cars and smart retail. Check out our open positions!

]
StoryTitle: The #paperoftheweek is “RelGAN: Multi-Domain Image-to-Image Translation via Relative Attributes”

An introduction to Machine Learning for Beginners Tutorial

Table of Contents:

  1. Introduction to Machine Learning
  • Applications of Machine learning
  • Types of Machine learning

2. Supervised Learning.

  • Types of Supervised Learning

3. Unsupervised Learning.

  • Algorithms of Unsupervised Learning

4. Reinforcement Learning.

5. Closing Summary

1.1 Introduction to Machine learning:

The term Machine Learning was coined by Arthur Samuel in 1959, an American pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence and stated that “it gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed”.

Machine Learning is a latest buzzword floating around. It deserves to, as it is one of the most interesting subfield of Computer Science. So what does Machine Learning really mean?

Machine Learning is a system that can learn from example through self-improvement and without being explicitly coded by programmer Or in simple words it is to teach the machines how to predict.

1.2 Applications of Machine Learning

Before we get started, here is a quick overview of what machine learning is capable of:

Healthcare: Predicting patient diagnostics for doctors to review

Social Network: Predicting certain match preferences on a dating website for better compatibility

Finance: Predicting fraudulent activity on a credit card

E-commerce: Predicting customer churn

Biology: Finding patterns in gene mutations that could represent cancer.

1.3 Types of Machine Learning

Machine learning is sub-categorized to three types:

  • Supervised learning
  • Unsupervised learning
  • Reinforcement learning

Now let’s see all the types one at a time:

2.1 What is Supervised Learning?

Supervised Learning is the one, where you have to guide the machine first. We have a dataset and we have to train the model or the machine. Once the model gets trained it can start making a prediction or decision when new data is given to it.

From the above image you can see that we have two items in the training dataset, so now we have to train our model so that the model can accurately predict which is apple and which is cupcake.

Now suppose after training the data, you have given a new separate item say cupcake and asked to identify it.

Since the machine has already learned the things from previous data and this time have to use it wisely. It will first classify the item with its shape and would confirm the item name as CUPCAKE and put it in that category. Thus the machine learns the things from training data and then apply the knowledge to test data(new item).

2.2 Types of Supervised learning:

  1. Regression is a technique that aims to reproduce the output value. We can use it, for example, to predict the price of some product, like a price of a house in a specific city or the value of a stock. There is a huge number of things we can predict if we wish to.
  2. Classification is a Supervised Learning task where output is having defined labels(discrete value). In binary classification, model predicts either 0 or 1 ; yes or no but in case of multi class classification, model predicts more than one class.

Now we will see what are the different examples of supervised machine learning.

Example of Supervised Learning Algorithm:

  • Linear Regression
  • Logistic Regression
  • Nearest Neighbor
  • Guassian naive Bayes
  • Decision Trees
  • Support Vector Machine (SVM)
  • Random Forest

Once we start building a machine learning model, we can discuss these algorithms in detail.

3.1 What is Unsupervised machine learning??

Unsupervised learning is the training of machine using information that is neither classified nor labeled and allowing the algorithm to act on that information without guidance. Here the task of machine is to group unsorted information according to similarities, patterns and differences without any prior training of data.

For instance, suppose consider the above image having Triangle,cube and circle which have not seen ever.

Thus the machine has no idea about the features these Shapes, so we can’t categorize it. But it can categorize them according to their similarities, patterns, and differences i.e., we can easily categorize the above picture into three parts. First may contain all shapes having Triangles, second part may contain all shapes having Cubes and third part may contain all shapes having Circles. Here you didn’t learn anything before, means no training data or examples.

3.2 Unsupervised learning classified into two categories of algorithms:

  • Clustering: A clustering problem is where you want to discover the inherent groupings in the data, such as grouping customers by purchasing behavior.
  • Association: An association rule learning problem is where you want to discover rules that describe large portions of your data, such as people that buy X also tend to buy Y.

4.1 What is Reinforcement learning???

Reinforcement learning is an area of Machine Learning. It is about taking suitable action to maximize reward in a particular situation.

Example of Reinforcement Learning

I hope you guys have played Super Mario game in your childhood. Say we have a computer program that plays the game Mario. It learns to control the character, receiving feedback from the environment in the form of a changing screen. Based on the successes (or failures) of our algorithm, it can learn to interact with the environment and improve by using the feedback it receives.

For more information on Reinforcement learning: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning

5.1 Closing Summary:

Till now I have covered the basics of Machine learning. I hope you guys got an idea about what Machine learning is. We have only just started. So in next post I will come up with practical examples and I will build a machine learning model in python.

]

Why we chose AWS over GCP for machine learning

And why we might’ve gotten it wrong

Caleb Kaiser
Follow
Apr 30 · 3 min read

About 10 months ago, a few of us began working on our model serving infrastructure. We wanted to build a tool that would take a trained model and turn it into a production web service, without us having to write glue code or wrangle AWS/Kubernetes for each deployment.

For our use cases and the test cases we ran it through, the tool worked great. When we open sourced it, however, we got an unexpected bit of feedback.

Cortex, our model serving tool, only supports AWS. Since we personally worked on AWS, and because we understood AWS to be the most popular cloud, we assumed multi-cloud support didn’t need to be much of a priority.

We seem to have been wrong about that one.

Since open-sourcing Cortex, our number one feature request far and away has been GCP support.

Why the machine learning community loves GCP

Before open-sourcing Cortex, we weighed adding in support for other clouds. We opted against it for two main reasons:

  • We weren’t sure that we’d be able to maintain multiple cloud integrations with just a few core contributors.
  • AWS is the most popular cloud by a decent margin—we assumed it would cover most of our users.

While the first point still has merit, the second may have been misguided.

AWS is the most popular cloud in general, but there is no good data on how popular each cloud is for machine learning specifically. Speaking anecdotally, feedback from our community suggests that GCP is much more popular within the ML community than its total market share reflects.

This makes sense for a few of reasons.

First, Google has done a good job of making the Google ecosystem the most cost effective place to get started with machine learning. At scale, the price differences between GCP and AWS might be less significant, but your first few thousand dollars take you a lot farther on GCP.

For example, Colab, Google’s cloud notebook environment, is free to use and offers complimentary access to GPUs/TPUs. Many ML projects, as a result, begin their lives in a Colab notebook.

GCP’s “Always Free” tier is also more appealing than AWS’s to ML practitioners. Core services like Cloud Run, Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE), and Google Compute Engine (GCE) all have a monthly free allowance, something AWS does not mirror. Additionally, for a long time, GKE’s control plane was free, whereas AWS’s was $0.20 per hour (though as of June 2020 they will both be $0.10 per hour).

Finally, Google’s $300 in free GCP credits is a more easily understandable promotion than the service-by-service trial lengths offered by AWS.

We still like AWS. EKS is a major part of our stack, and for well-funded machine learning teams, these differences aren’t major. But since open-sourcing Cortex, we’ve heard from many users who aren’t working at large enterprise companies—startups, students, and researchers, for example—for whom GCP’s early-stage cost-effectiveness has a lot of appeal.

Cortex belongs to the machine learning—not AWS—ecosystem

To be clear, the issue we face isn’t that Cortex supports AWS. The issue we face is that Cortex only supports one cloud. Put another way, Cortex’s primary focus is on developer experience, and being de facto locked in to one cloud is a suboptimal experience.

While focusing on one cloud at the start helped us build quickly, we are ultimately building Cortex for developers who want to use machine learning in production. While AWS represents a large chunk of that population, no cloud covers it comprehensively.

To address this, we’ve spent the last few months testing out GCP, and have begun work on integrating Cortex with GCP (and eventually, other clouds).

We don’t have a firm release date yet, but we’re very excited to take another step towards cloud agnosticism in the near future.

Interested in machine learning infrastructure? We’re always happy to hear from new contributors—even if it’s just to ask for GCP support :)

]
StoryTitle: Why we chose AWS over GCP for machine learning
